editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: SERMON. I.Vol. VI. Concerning the Perfection of God.

q.p: Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in Heaven is perfect.

div.p:
THESE words are the Conclu≈øion which our Saviour draws from tho≈øe Precepts which he had given his Di≈øciples of greater perfection, than any Laws that were extant in the world before. V. 44. I ≈øay unto you, love your Enemies, ble≈øs them that cur≈øe you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for tho≈øe that de≈øpitefully u≈øe you, and per≈øecute you. And to per≈øwade them hereto, he propounds to them the Pattern of the Divine Perfection; telling them, that being thus affected towards their Enemies, they ≈øhould re≈øemble God, v. 45.
That ye may be the Children of your heavenly Father; for he maketh the Sun to ri≈øe on the evil, and on the good, and ≈øendeth Rain on the ju≈øt, and on the unju≈øt.

And then he tells us, that if we be not thus affected towards our Enemies, and tho≈øe that have been injurious to us, we are ≈øo far from being like God, that we are but ju≈øt level with the wor≈øt of Men, v. 46, 47. For if ye love them which love you, what reward have you? do not even the Publicans the ≈øame? And if ye ≈øalute your Brethren only, what do ye more than others? do not even the Publicans ≈øo? And then concludes, that if we would attain that perfection which the Chri≈øtian Religion de≈øigns to advance Men to, we mu≈øt endeavour to be like God in the≈øe perfections of Goodne≈øs, and Mercy, and Patience; Be ye therefore perfect, as your Father which is in Heaven is perfect. In which words we have,
Fir≈øt, The ab≈øolute Perfection of the Divine Nature ≈øuppo≈øed; as your Father which is in Heaven is perfect.
Secondly, It is propounded as a Pattern to our imitation. Be ye therefore perfect, &c.
In handling of the≈øe words, I ≈øhall do the≈øe four things.
I. Con≈øider how we are to conceive of the Divine Perfection.
II. I ≈øhall lay down ≈øome Rules whereby we may govern and rectifie our Opinions concerning the Attributes and Perfections of God.
III. How far we are to imitate the Perfections of God, and particularly what tho≈øe Divine Qualities are, which our Saviour doth here more e≈øpecially propound to our imitation.

IV. I ≈øhall endeavour to clear the true meaning of this Precept, and to ≈øhew that the Duty here intended by our Saviour is not impo≈ø≈øible to us; and then conclude this Di≈øcour≈øe with ≈øome u≈øeful Inferences from the whole.
I. I ≈øhall con≈øider how we are to conceive of the Divine Perfections. The≈øe two ways.
1. By a≈øcribing all imaginable and po≈ø≈øible Perfection to God.
2. By ≈øeparating and removing all manner of Imperfection from him.

1. By a≈øcribing all imaginable, and po≈ø≈øible Perfection to God; ab≈øolute and univer≈øal Perfection, not limited to a certain kind, or to certain particulars; but whatever we can conceive, and imagin to be a Perfection, is to be a≈øcribed to him;
yea and beyond this, whatever po≈ø≈øible Perfection there is, or po≈ø≈øible degree of any Perfection, which our ≈øhort Under≈øtandings cannot conceive or comprehend, is to be a≈øcribed to him. For we are not to confine the Perfection of God to our imagination, as if we could find out the Almighty to Perfection: But on the contrary, to believe the Perfection of the Divine Nature to be boundle≈øs and unlimited, and infinitely to exceed our highe≈øt thoughts and apprehen≈øions.

More particularly, all kinds and all degrees of Perfection are to be a≈øcribed to God, which either do not imply a plain Contradiction, or do not argue ≈øome Imperfection, or are not evidently incon≈øi≈øtent with ≈øome other and greater Perfection.

Some things may ≈øeem to be Perfections, which in truth are not; becau≈øe they are plainly impo≈ø≈øible, and involve a Contradiction; as that what has once been, ≈øhould by any Power be made not to have been; or that a thing, which by its Nature is limited and confin'd to one place, ≈øhould at the ≈øame time be in another. The≈øe things in Rea≈øon are impo≈ø≈øible, and therefore not to be ≈øuppo≈øed to fall under any Power how unlimited
≈øoever. For if we once a≈øcribe Contradictions to God, we de≈øtroy his Being; becau≈øe then to be, and not to be, Power, and no Power would be all one.

And then there are ≈øome Perfections, which do argue and ≈øuppo≈øe Imperfections in them; as Motion, the quickne≈øs and ≈øwiftne≈øs thereof in Creatures is a Perfection, but then it ≈øuppo≈øeth a finite and limited Nature: For a boundle≈øs and immen≈øe Being, that is every where pre≈øent at once, hath no need to move from one place to another; and therefore though Motion be a Perfection in Creatures, there is no Rea≈øon to a≈øcribe it to God, becau≈øe it ≈øuppo≈øeth a greater Imperfection.

And there are al≈øo ≈øome imaginable degrees of Perfection, which becau≈øe they are incon≈øi≈øtent with other Perfections, are not to be admitted in the Divine Nature. For in≈øtance, ≈øuch degrees of Goodne≈øs and Mercy may be imagined, as would quite exclude and ≈øhut out Ju≈øtice; and on the other hand ≈øuch a ≈øtrictne≈øs and a rigour of Ju≈øtice, as would leave no room at all for Patience and Mercy; and therefore ≈øuch degrees are not really to be e≈øteemed Perfections. For this is a certain truth, that nothing is a Divine Perfection,
which evidently cla≈øheth with any other nece≈ø≈øary and e≈ø≈øential Perfection of the Divine Nature. We mu≈øt ≈øo con≈øider the Perfections of God, that they may accord and con≈øi≈øt together; and therefore it cannot be a Perfection of God to be ≈øo good and gracious, as to encourage Sin, and to overthrow the Reverence of his own Laws and Government. 'Tis not Goodne≈øs, but Ea≈øine≈øs and Weakne≈øs, to be contented to be perpetually injur'd and affronted. 'Tis not Patience, to be willing to be everla≈øtingly trampled upon. So likewi≈øe on the other hand, 'tis not a Perfection to be ≈øo ≈øevere and rigorous, as to ≈ømite a Sinner in the in≈øtant that he offends, not to be able to refrain from Puni≈øhment, and to give time for Repentance.

But whatever Perfection is conceivable or po≈ø≈øible, and argues no Imperfection, nor is repugnant to any other nece≈ø≈øary Perfection, is to be a≈øcribed to God; for this is the mo≈øt natural and ea≈øie conception that we can have of God, that he is the mo≈øt perfect Being. This natural Light doth fir≈øt ≈øugge≈øt and offer to the Minds of Men, and we cannot conceive of God as meer Power and Will without Wi≈ødom and Goodne≈øs. Hence it is that the
Greeks call God very often, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the be≈øt of Beings, and the Latin Optimus, Maximus, the be≈øt and the Greate≈øt, beati≈ø≈øima & perfecti≈ø≈øima natura, con≈øtans & perfecta Ratio, the happie≈øt and mo≈øt perfect Nature, immutible and ab≈øolute Rea≈øon; and many other ≈øuch expre≈ø≈øions which we meet with in the Writings of the Heathen Philo≈øophers. I readily grant, that the fir≈øt and mo≈øt obvious thought which men have of God, is that of his Greatne≈øs and Maje≈øty; but this nece≈ø≈øarily involves or infers his Goodne≈øs; as Seneca excellently rea≈øons, Primus Deorum cultus e≈øt Deos credere, dein reddere illis maje≈øtatem ≈øuam, reddere bonitatem, ≈øine qu√¢ nulla Maje≈øtas, The fir≈øt Wor≈øhip of the Gods is to believe their Being; next to a≈øcribe to them Greatne≈øs and Maje≈øty, to a≈øcribe to them Goodne≈øs, without which there can be no Maje≈øty.

And we ≈øhall find all along in Plato, & Tully, and the be≈øt and wi≈øe≈øt Writers among the Heathen, that they every where attribute the highe≈øt Excellencies and Perfections to the Divine Nature, and do ≈øteer and govern all their Di≈øcour≈øes of God by this Principle, that Perfection is to be a≈øcrbied to him: And
whenever any thing is ≈øaid of God, they examin whether it be a Perfection or not; if it be, they give it him as his due; if it be not, they lay it a≈øide, as a thing not fit to be ≈øpoken of him.

And in the Scripture we do every where find Perfection a≈øcribed to the Nature, and Works, and Laws of God, to every thing that belongs to him, or proceeds from him: Job 37.16. Do≈øt thou know the wondrous works of him that is perfect in knowledge? And again, Can≈øt thou by ≈øearching find out God? Can'≈øt thou find out the Almighty to perfection? P≈ø. 18.30 As for God his way is perfect P≈ø. 19.7. The Law of the Lord is perfect.

I ≈øhall not need to con≈øider particularly the ≈øeveral Perfections of the Divine Nature, I ≈øhall only give you a brief Scheme and Draught of them. Whatever Perfection can be imagined either in the manner of Being or Acting is to be a≈øcribed to God; therefore as to his Nature we ≈øay that he is a Spirit, that is, that he is not meer Body or Matter, becau≈øe that would exclude ≈øeveral other Perfections; for meer Matter is incapable both of Knowledge and Liberty, being determined by nece≈ø≈øary Laws of Motion; and yet without Knowledge and
Liberty, there can be no Wi≈ødom nor Goodne≈øs. We ≈øay of God, that he is of him≈øelf, and without Cau≈øe, and does not owe his Being to any other; and con≈øequently that he is nece≈ø≈øarily, and that he cannot but be, and cannot be otherwi≈øe than he is; for that which is of its ≈øelf did not chu≈øe whether it would be or not, nor whether it would be thus or otherwi≈øe; for to ≈øuppo≈øe any thing to deliberate or con≈øult about it's own Being, is to ≈øuppo≈øe it to be before it is.

We mu≈øt ≈øay of God likewi≈øe that he is immen≈øe, and every where pre≈øent, becau≈øe to be limited is an Imperfection; and that he is eternal, that is, ever was, and ≈øhall be; for to cea≈øe to be, is a greater Imperfection than ≈øometime not to have been.

And then we are to ≈øay of God, that he is the Cau≈øe of all other Beings, that they are made by him and depend upon him; that he knows all things, and can do all things in the mo≈øt perfect manner, by a glance of his Mind, and by the meer beck and nod of his Will, without long ≈øtudy or deliberation, without laborious pains and endeavours, and con≈øequently that nothing is exempted from his Knowledge, and
Power, and Providence, and that he admini≈øters all things in a way of Goodne≈øs and Wi≈ødom, of Ju≈øtice and Truth; and therefore all things are to be referred to him, as their la≈øt end. All the≈øe Perfections, and all other that are po≈ø≈øible, we are to look upon the Divine Nature as fully and immutably po≈ø≈øe≈øt of, and that in an higher and more excellent degree, than our finite Under≈øtandings are able to conceive or comprehend.

2. As we are to a≈øcribe all imaginable, po≈ø≈øible Perfections to God, ≈øo we are to ≈øeparate and remove all manner of Imperfection from him. We mu≈øt not ob≈øcure or blemi≈øh the Divine Nature with the lea≈øt ≈øhadow or blot of Imperfection. If we once admit of this, to a≈øcribe any thing to God which argues Imperfection, we ≈øtrike at the foundation, and de≈øtroy one of the cleare≈øt and mo≈øt e≈ø≈øential Notions, which Men have of God. And therefore we find the Scripture very careful to remove all kind of natural or moral Imperfection from God. Gen. 18.25. That be far from Thee to do after this manner, to ≈ølay the righteous with the wicked, and that the righteous ≈øhould be as the wicked,
that be far from thee; ≈øhall not the Judge of all the world do right? Deut. 32.4. A God of truth and without iniquity. Rom. 9.14. What ≈øhall we ≈øay then, is there unrighteou≈øne≈øs with God? God forbid, far be it from him.

Hence it is that in Scripture Holine≈øs is ≈øo frequently a≈øcrib'd to God, which ≈øignifies the purity and freedom of the Divine Nature from that which we call Sin; and God is very ≈øolicitous to give us ≈øuch a notion of him≈øelf, as may remove Sin and unrighteou≈øne≈øs at the greate≈øt di≈øtance from him, becau≈øe that is the greate≈øt of Imperfections. Is it an Imperfection to countenance Sin? the Scripture acquits God of it. P≈øal. 5.4, 5. Thou art not a God that hath plea≈øure in wickedne≈øs, neither ≈øhall evil dwell with Thee. Is it an Imperfection to go from ones word, or to change ones mind? this likewi≈øe is remov'd from God. 1 Sam. 15.29. The ≈øtrength of I≈ørael will not lie or repent, he is not a man, that he ≈øhould repent. Is it an Imperfection to want any thing, to be liable to any thing, to depend upon any thing without one's ≈øelf for their happine≈øs? this al≈øo is to be ≈øet far from him. Job 22.2, 3. Can a man be profitable to God? or is it a gain
to him, that thou make≈øt thy way perfect? Job 35.6, 7. If thou ≈øinne≈øt, what do≈øt thou again≈øt him? or if thy tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions be multiplied, what do≈øt thou unto him? If thou art righteous, what give≈øt thou him? or what receiveth he of thine hand? Thy wickedne≈øs may hurt a man as thou art, and thy righteou≈øne≈øs may profit the Son of man. Is it an Imperfection to tempt, or to be tempted to Sin? this is to be ≈øeparated from God, He cannot be tempted of evil, neither tempteth he any man, ≈øaith St. James. Chap. 1.17. And to mention no more, is it an Imperfection to be in any re≈øpect mutable? This is denyed of God, with him there is no variablene≈øs, or ≈øhadow of turning. Thus you ≈øee how we are to conceive of the Perfections of God, by a≈øcribing all imaginable and po≈ø≈øible Perfection to him, and removing all ≈øhadow of Imperfection from him. I proceed in the
II. Place, to lay down ≈øome Rules by which we may rectifie and govern our Opinions concerning the Attributes and Perfections of God: The be≈øt I can think of, are the≈øe following.

Fir≈øt, Let us begin with the mo≈øt natural, and plain, and ea≈øie Perfections of God, and lay them for a foundation,
and rectifie all our other Apprehen≈øions of God, and Rea≈øonings about him, by the≈øe; and the≈øe are his Power, Wi≈ødom, and Goodne≈øs, to which mo≈øt of the re≈øt may be reduced. Right Apprehen≈øions and a firm Belief of the≈øe will make it ea≈øily credible to us, that all things were made and are governed, by him; for his Goodne≈øs will di≈øpo≈øe and incline him to communicate Being to other things, and to take care of them when they are made. An infinite Power and Wi≈ødom render him able to do all this without any labour or difficulty, and without any di≈øturbance of his ea≈øe or happine≈øs, as Epicurus would ≈øeem vainly to fear; who in truth did not believe a God, but pretended only to deny his Providence, and that he either made or govern'd the world; becau≈øe he was loth to lay ≈øo much trouble upon him. Vain man! as if tho≈øe things which are impo≈ø≈øible and difficult to our Weakne≈øs and Folly, might not be infinitely ea≈øie to infinite Power and Wi≈ødom.

Particularly the Goodne≈øs and Ju≈øtice of God are not ≈øo difficult to apprehend, as the Di≈øputes and Controver≈øies about them have rendred them
to many. When we con≈øider infinite Knowledge and Power, we may ea≈øily lo≈øe our ≈øelves, and go out of our depth, by wading too far into them: There is ≈øomething concerning the≈øe, that is unimaginable, and unaccountable to our Rea≈øon; we may not be able to under≈øtand how Something may be produc'd from Nothing; becau≈øe it argues ≈øuch an exce≈øs of Power, as we cannot comprehend; but yet we are forc'd to acknowledge, that either the World mu≈øt be produc'd from Nothing, or that Matter was eternally of it ≈øelf, which is every whit as hard to imagine, as that infinite Power ≈øhould be able to produce it from nothing. So likewi≈øe we are not able to conceive, how God can certainly know future Events, which depend upon voluntary and uncertain Cau≈øes, becau≈øe we cannot comprehend infinite Knowledge; but this we may ea≈øily be ≈øatisfied in, that infinite Power and Knowledge may be able to do, and know many things, which we cannot conceive how they can be known or done, no more than a Child can imagine how a great Mathematician can demon≈øtrate his Propo≈øitions. Only this we are ≈øure
of, as we can be of any thing, that no Power can do that which is evidently impo≈ø≈øible, and implies a plain Contradiction.

div.head: SERMON II.Vol. VI. Concerning our imitation of the Divine Perfections.

q.p: Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in Heaven is perfect.

div.p: IN the≈øe words we have, Fir≈øt, The ab≈øolute Perfection of the Divine Nature ≈øuppo≈øed, not only in tho≈øe before mentioned, of Goodne≈øs, and Mercy, and Patience; but in all other Excellencies what≈øoever.

The two fir≈øt I have already ≈øpoken to, I now proceed to the third particular, which is to ≈øhew how far we are to imitate the Perfections of God, and particularly what tho≈øe Divine Qualities are, which our Saviour doth here more e≈øpecially propound to our imitation. For though the≈øe words do ≈øuppo≈øe the ab≈øolute Perfection of the Divine Nature, yet becau≈øe there are ≈øeveral Perfections of God which are incommunicable, and a Creature, as ≈øuch, is utterly incapable of them, the≈øe cannot be ≈øuppos'd to be intended for

So that in our imitation of the Divine Perfection, we are to keep within the ≈øtation of Creatures, not affecting an Independency and Soveraignty like the mo≈øt high, and to be Omnipotent as he is, to have an arm like God, and to thunder with a voice like him, as the expre≈ø≈øion is in Job: But to endeavour to re≈øemble him, pro modulo creaturae, according to the rate and capacity

For that which our Saviour here in the Text more peculiarly recommends
to our imitation, is the Goodne≈øs of God, of which his Mercy and Patience are two eminent Branches. The Mercy of God is his Goodne≈øs to tho≈øe that are in Mi≈øery, or are liable to it. Be ye therefore; this Particle of inference, therefore, hath a plain relation to ≈øomething ≈øpoken before; and if we look back to v. 44. we ≈øhall find our Saviour there enjoyning his Di≈øciples to love their Enemies, to ble≈øs them that cur≈øe them, to do good to them that hate them, and to pray for tho≈øe that de≈øpightfully u≈øe them, and per≈øecute them. So that though the univer≈øal Perfection of the Divine Nature be here ≈øuppo≈øed, yet the Attributes of his Goodne≈øs, and Mercy, and Patience, are here particularly pointed at, and propounded to us for our Pattern; and the Precept of imitating the Divine Perfection is more e≈øpecially to be under≈øtood of tho≈øe Perfections which our Saviour had been di≈øcour≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of before, viz. the Goodne≈øs and Mercy of God. 4. I. I will con≈øider what we are to under≈øtand by the ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs or happine≈øs of God, and what are the e≈ø≈øential Ingredients of it. But God is an Eternal Spring of Light, which never ri≈øeth or ≈øets, which hath no mixture of ≈øhadow nor darkne≈øs, hath no changes nor variations, but is always the ≈øame free and liberal di≈øpen≈øer of good things to his Creatures; the Father of Lights, with whom is no variablene≈øs nor ≈øhadow of turning; which Words ≈øignifie the immutable perfection and goodne≈øs of the Divine Nature, which ≈øhall (by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) be the ≈øubject of my pre≈øent Di≈øcour≈øe; In which I ≈øhall proceed in this Method.

I. For the Explication of it. By the immutability of God, we mean that he always is, and was, and to all Eternity will be the ≈øame, that he undergoes no changes either of his E≈ø≈øence and Being, or of his Properties and Perfections. I proceed to the

III. All that now remains is to apply this Doctrine of the immutability of the Divine Nature to our ≈øelves; and the Con≈øideration of it may ≈øerve to ≈øeveral good Purpo≈øes, both in reference to bad and good Men.
Fir≈øt, In regard to ≈øinners and wicked Men.

And, 1≈øt. The unchangeablene≈øs of God is matter of great terrour to wicked Men. 2ly. The con≈øideration of Gods unchangeablene≈øs, ≈øhould likewi≈øe be a very powerful Argument to urge Sinners to Repententance. At what in≈øtant I ≈øhall ≈øpeak concerning a nation, and concerning a kingdom, to pluck up, and to pull down, and to de≈øtroy it, if that nation again≈øt whom I have pronounced, turn from their evil, I will repent of the evil that I thought to do unto them; and ≈øo likewi≈øe when his faithful People and Servants are in great Di≈øtre≈øs, and there is no vi≈øible help and means of relief, in this ca≈øe likewi≈øe God is ≈øaid to repent

div.head: SERMON V.Vol. VI. The Knowledge of God

q.p: The Lord is a God of Knowledge.

div.p:
I Come now to ≈øpeak of tho≈øe Properties and Perfections which relate to the Divine Under≈øtanding, and Will, and Manner, and Power of acting. The Knowledge of God is a perfect comprehen≈øion of the Nature of all things, with all their Powers, and Qualities, and Circum≈øtances; the Wi≈ødom of God is a perfect Comprehen≈øion
of the Re≈øpects and Relations of things one to another; of their Harmony and Oppo≈øition; of their fitne≈øs and unfitne≈øs to ≈øuch and ≈øuch Ends. The Knowledge of God only implies his bare Under≈øtanding of Things; but his Wi≈ødom implies the Skill of ordering and di≈øpo≈øing things to the be≈øt Ends and Purpo≈øes, to make every thing, and to govern and admini≈øter all things in Number, Weight, and Mea≈øure. I ≈øhall, at pre≈øent ≈øpeak of the fir≈øt of the≈øe, the Knowledge of God, which, as I ≈øaid, is a perfect Comprehen≈øion of the Nature of all things, and of every thing belonging to their Nature; of the Powers, and Qualities, and Circum≈øtances of things.
The≈øe Words ≈øignifie God to be the Fountain of Knowledge; that is, that he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth it him≈øelf, and communicates it to others. In the handling of this, I ≈øhall
Fir≈øt, Endeavour to prove, that this Attribute belongs to God.
Secondly, Shew the Perfection and the Prerogatives of the Divine Knowledge.

Fir≈øt, For the proof of it, I ≈øhall attempt it two ways.

div.p: 1. From the Dictates of Natural Light and Rea≈øon. I begin with this fir≈øt, becau≈øe, unle≈øs this be e≈øtabli≈øh'd, all Divine Revelation falls to the ground; unle≈øs Natural Rea≈øon a≈ø≈øures us, That God is endowed with Knowledge and ∆≤nder≈øtanding, it is in vain to enquire after Divine Revelation. For to make any Revelation credible, two things are requi≈øite on the part of the Revealer, Ability and Integrity; that he have a perfect Knowledge and ∆≤nder≈øtanding of the thing which he reveals, ≈øo that he cannot be deceived him≈øelf; and ≈øo much Goodne≈øs and Truth that he will not deceive us. div.p:
1≈øt. God perfectly knows the hearts of Men, Jer. 17.10. I the Lord ≈øearch the hearts and try the reins; where by heart and reins, which are the mo≈øt inward parts of the Body; and lie lea≈øt open to di≈øcovery, are ≈øignified the mo≈øt ≈øecret Thoughts and Motions of the Soul, the≈øe God is ≈øaid to ≈øearch and try, not as if it were a work of Labour and Difficulty to the Divine Knowledge to penetrate the hearts of Men, and to dive into their Thoughts, but to ≈øignifie to us the Perfection and Exactne≈øs of the Divine Knowledge; as when Men would know a thing exactly, they ≈øearch into every part of it, and examine every thing narrowly;
≈øo God is ≈øaid to ≈øearch the heart, to ≈øignifie to us that he knows the hearts of Men, as throughly as we do any thing upon the ≈øtricte≈øt Search and mo≈øt diligent Examination; upon the ≈øame account he is ≈øaid el≈øewhere in Scripture to weigh the Spirits of Men, Prov. 16.2. All the ways of Man are clean in his own eyes, but the Lord weigheth the Spirits; that is, he hath as perfect a Knowledge of the ≈øecret Motions and Inclinations of Mens hearts, as Men have of tho≈øe things which they weigh in a Ballance with the greate≈øt exactne≈øs.

Now that God hath this perfect Knowledge of Mens hearts, the Scripture frequently declares to us; that he knows the hearts of all Men, 1 Kings 8.39. For thou, even thou knowe≈øt the hearts of all the Children of Men. 1 Chron. 28.9. The Lord ≈øearcheth all hearts, and under≈øtandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts. How clo≈øe and re≈øerved ≈øoever Men may be, what di≈øgui≈øe ≈øoever they may u≈øe to hide their purpo≈øes from Men, yet God ≈øees them; the things which are mo≈øt dark and ≈øecret are open to his view, P≈øal. 44.21. He knoweth the ≈øecrets of the hearts,
Prov. 15.11. Hell and De≈øtruction are before him, how much more the hearts of the Children of Men? Whatever pretences Men may make, God ≈øees through them, and di≈øcovers the very intentions of their hearts. P≈øal. 7.9. The righteous Lord tryeth the hearts and reins. Heb. 4.13. It is ≈øaid there of the Word of God, that it is a di≈øcerner of the thoughts and intentions of the Heart; for all things are naked and open to the Eye of him with whom we have to do, and there is no Creature that is not manife≈øt in his ≈øight; nay he knows our thoughts at a di≈øtance, what they will be, before they actually are, P≈øal. 139.2. Thou knowe≈øt my thoughts afar off. 'Tis true indeed every Man is con≈øcious to his own Thoughts, and privy to the Motions of his own Mind, when they are pre≈øent, and when they are pa≈øt, if he have not forgot them; but no Man knows what he ≈øhall think to morrow, but this God knows, for he knows us more intimately and throughly than we do our ≈øelves; God is greater than our hearts, and knows all things, 1 John 3.20.

And tho' the Scripture had not revealed this ≈øo plainly, yet we had not
been wholly ignorant of it; it is a Principle implanted in us, and born with us, as being part of that natural Notion which Men have of God; the Rea≈øon of our Minds tells us that God knows our Hearts; and the Fears and Jealou≈øies of our Minds are an Evidence of it.

(1≈øt.) The Rea≈øon of every Man's mind tells him, that the Supreme Being, whom we call God, is endowed with all Perfection, and among his other Perfections, that he excels in Knowledge; and to the Perfection of Knowledge it is required, that it extend it ≈øelf to all Objects, and that nothing be exempted from it. The Knowledge of God in re≈øpect of all Objects, is like the Sun, in re≈øpect of this lower World, nothing is hid from the light of it. We have naturally this Apprehen≈øion of God, that he is an immen≈øe Being, every where pre≈øent, that he intimately penetrates all places and things, and con≈øequently that he is pre≈øent to our Spirits, and ≈øees all the motions of our Minds, and di≈øcerns the very ≈øecrets of our Hearts; and there can be no ≈øuch thing as ≈øecre≈øie and retirement from an Eye that is every
where, and a Knowledge that pierceth into all things.

And to convince us that the≈øe are the dictates of Natural Rea≈øon, without the help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Divine Revelation, we ≈øhall find that the Heathen, who had only the advantage of Natural Light, were firmly po≈ø≈øe≈øt with this apprehen≈øion, that God knows the hearts of Men. This may be ≈øufficiently Collected from the frequent ≈øayings of the wi≈øer Heathens to this purpo≈øe; that the be≈øt and mo≈øt acceptable wor≈øhip of the Deity is that which is inward, that of the Heart and Mind. To this Sen≈øe Tully ≈øpeaks, Cultus autem deorum e≈øt optimus, idemque ca≈øti≈ø≈øimus atque ≈øancti≈ø≈øimus pleni≈ø≈øimu≈øque pietatis, ut eos ≈øemper pur√¢, integr√¢ atque incorrupt√¢ mente & voce veneremur, The be≈øt and holie≈øt wor≈øhip of the Gods is to wor≈øhip them with a pure and upright and ≈øincere Mind. To the ≈øame purpo≈øe is that known ≈øaying of the Poet,
Compo≈øitum jus fa≈øque animi, ≈øancto≈øque rece≈ø≈øus
Mentis, & incoctum genero≈øo pectus hone≈øto,
Haec cedo ut admoveam templis & farre litabo;
Do but offer to God a mind inwardly re≈øolved to be ju≈øt and hone≈øt, and the plaine≈øt ≈øacrifice will plea≈øe him. Now from hence, that they judged the purity of our Hearts and Thoughts, and an hone≈øt di≈øpo≈øition of Mind, to be mo≈øt acceptable to their Gods, we may certainly conclude, that they did mo≈øt firmly believe that God knows the Secrets of Mens Hearts; otherwi≈øe there had been no need for Men to endeavour to recommend them≈øelves this way to the Divine acceptance.

But we need not argue this by con≈øequence, there are many expre≈øs pa≈ø≈øages in their Writings, which do ≈øufficiently ≈øignifie their belief of this Principle. Thales, one of their mo≈øt ancient Philo≈øophers, being askt, if an unju≈øt Man could conceal him≈øelf from God, he an≈øwer'd, he cannot ≈øo much as hide from him the very thoughts and de≈øign of it. Socrates (as Xenophon tells us) was wont to inculcate this Principle upon his Scholar, that the Gods know all things, what we ≈øay, and what we do, and what we think in ≈øilence. To the ≈øame purpo≈øe Arrian in his Di≈ø≈øertations
upon Epictetus laying down the Principles of a virtuous life, fir≈øt of all, ≈øaith he, we mu≈øt learn this, that there is a God who takes care of the World, and that there is nothing hid from him, not only what we do, but not ≈øo much as what we think, and de≈øign. So likewi≈øe Tully in his Book of Laws, let every Man be firmly per≈øwaded of this, that the Gods ≈øee what every Man is, and with what Mind and Devotion they ≈øerve them: I will add but one Te≈øtimony more, and that is of Seneca in his Epi≈øtles, nihil Deo clau≈øum e≈øt, intere≈øt animis no≈øtris, & cogitationibus mediis intervenit, we can keep nothing clo≈øe from God, for he is pre≈øent to our Minds, and intimate to our Thoughts; ≈øo that you ≈øee this Principle is deeply rooted in the Minds of Men, and that Men do naturally Rea≈øon them≈øelves into it.

(2.) The natural fears of Men are likewi≈øe a ≈øecret acknowledgement of this; and I take this to be a great Truth, that a Man's natural Actions, and ≈øuch as happen upon Surpri≈øe and without Deliberation, are a better argument of the intimate ≈øen≈øe of our Minds, and do more truly di≈øcover what lies at the bottom of our Hearts, and what Notions are natural,
to us, than our contrived and deliberate Di≈øcour≈øe. If I ≈øee a Man upon the ≈øudden ≈øight of a Serpent recoil and ≈øtart back, tho' he tell me never ≈øo often that he is not afraid, yet I am ≈øufficiently convinc'd of the contrary, becau≈øe I ≈øee in his Countenance and Carriage a natural acknowledgment of Fear and Danger: ≈øo if Men find that upon the de≈øigning of a ≈øecret Wickedne≈øs, which never went further than their own Hearts, their Con≈øciences do ≈øting and la≈øh them, that they have a ≈øen≈øe of Guilt, and feel inward Frights and Horrours, whatever they may ≈øay to the contrary, this is a natural acknowledgment of an invi≈øible Eye that ≈øees them, and di≈øallows their wicked De≈øigns. If that be true which the Heathen Poet ≈øays, That Scelus intra ≈øe tacitum qui cogitat ullum, Facti crimen habet. He that meditates any ≈øecret Wickedne≈øs in his Heart, is guilty to him≈øelf, as if he had committed it; this is a plain Confe≈ø≈øion, that the Man ≈øtands in Awe of ≈øomething be≈øides Him≈øelf, and is jealous that there is one that is Con≈øcious to what he thinks.

2. That to have a perfect and thorough knowledge of Mens Hearts, is the peculiar Prerogative of God. This is imply'd in the An≈øwer to that Que≈øtion, Who can know the heart of man? Jer. 17.10. I the Lord ≈øearch the heart, and try the reins; this is the Prerogative of God, and one of his chief Titles, that he is „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a knower of the heart, 1 King. 8.39. Thou, even thou only knowe≈øt the hearts of all the children of men. Men may make a probable conjecture at the Thoughts and De≈øigns of others, from their Words and Actions; but God only knows them. Men are con≈øcious to their own Thoughts and Purpo≈øes, the ≈øpirit of a man that is in him, knows the things of a man; but they cannot ≈øee into the Secrets of another Man's Mind; 'tis God alone that knows the Hearts of all Men. The Heart of Man is a priviledg'd place, and the ≈øecret and inward workings of it are not ≈øubject to the cogni≈øance of any but God alone. The limits of Humane Knowledge are the outward appearances of Actions, 1 Sam. 16.7. The Lord ≈øeeth not as man ≈øeeth; for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the heart; our Knowledge is but ≈øuperficial, and glides upon the out≈øide
and ≈øurface of things, but the Divine Knowledge pierceth to the very center of every thing. Now the darke≈øt place, the mo≈øt inward retirement, the private≈øt Clo≈øet in the whole World, is the Heart of Man, and this God only is privy to; Deus autor omnium & ≈øpeculator omnium, √† quo nihil ≈øecretum e≈ø≈øe pote≈øt, tenebris intere≈øt, intere≈øt & cogitationibus no≈øtris qua≈øi alteris tenebris, ≈øaith Min. Foelix, God made all things, and ≈øees all things, and therefore nothing can be ≈øecret from him; he is pre≈øent in Darkne≈øs, and he is pre≈øent to the Thoughts of Men, which are as it were another and a thicker Darkne≈øs.

The Devil indeed pretends to this Knowledge; he would take upon him to know the integrity of Job's Heart better than God him≈øelf, and that notwith≈øtanding the Te≈øtimony which God gave of his Integrity, yet if he were but ≈øoundly tried by Affliction, he would renounce God, and cur≈øe him to his face: but the event proved how groundle≈øs and malicious this ≈øugge≈øtion was. But there is a far greater difficulty in this matter, from the pa≈ø≈øages of ≈øome Divines concerning the Devil's immediate acce≈øs to the Minds of Men, and
his Power to ca≈øt in Wicked Thoughts into them; which ≈øeems by con≈øequence to grant him ≈øome knowledge of Mens Hearts; for by the ≈øame Rea≈øon that he can imprint Thoughts upon Mens Minds, he may ≈øee tho≈øe that are imprinted there.

That the Devil is a very ≈øagacious Spirit, and can make very ≈øhrewd Conjectures at the bent and inclinations of Mens Minds, and the probable workings of our Thoughts, from a general Knowledge and Ob≈øervation of our Tempers and Pa≈ø≈øions, of our Intere≈øts and De≈øigns, and from the general tenour of our Actions in Publick and Private, and from our Prayers and Confe≈ø≈øions to God (if he permit him at any time to be ≈øo near Good Men) I think there is no doubt: but this is far from a Knowledge of our Hearts; all this is but Conjecture, and ≈øuch as men may make of one another in a lower degree.
But as to the bu≈øine≈øs of ca≈øting in bla≈øphemous and de≈øpairing Thoughts into the Minds of Men, to this I would ≈øay the≈øe three things.

1. That there are few of the≈øe ca≈øes which may not more probably be re≈øolved
into the Wickedne≈øs and Infidelity of Mens Hearts, or into the Darkne≈øs and Melancholy of our tempers, which are apt to rai≈øe and ≈øugge≈øt ≈øtrange Thoughts to Men, and ≈øuch as we may be apt to think have no ri≈øe from our ≈øelves, not con≈øidering what an odd and ≈øtrange influence the di≈øorder of our bodily Humours may have upon our Minds, as we ≈øee in violent Fevers, and ≈øeveral other Di≈øea≈øes; and Melancholy, tho' the workings of it are more ≈øtill and quiet, is as truly a Di≈øea≈øe as any other; ≈øo that I chu≈øe rather to a≈øcribe as much of the≈øe to a bodily Di≈øtemper as may be, becau≈øe it is a very uncomfortable con≈øideration, to think that the Devil hath ≈øuch an immediate Power upon the Minds of Men.

2. I do not ≈øee how by any means it can be granted, without prejudice to this Prerogative of God, which the Scripture plainly gives him, of being the only Knower of the Heart, that the Devil can have ≈øo immediate an acce≈øs to our Minds, as to put wicked Thoughts into them; nor can I think, that when it is ≈øaid, 1 Chron. 21.1. That Satan provoked David to number the people, and Luke 22.3. That the devil entred into Judas,
and Acts 5.3. That Satan had filled the heart of Ananias to lie unto the Holy Gho≈øt, and Eph. 2.2. That the devil is the ≈øpirit that worketh in the children of di≈øobedience; I ≈øay I cannot think that any or all of the≈øe expre≈ø≈øions do amount to ≈øuch an immediate power of putting wicked Thoughts into Mens Minds, but they only ≈øignifie that the Devil hath a greater hand in ≈øome ≈øins than others, and that a Heart wickedly bent and inclined give him a great advantage to tempt Men more powerfully, by pre≈øenting the occa≈øions of ≈øuck wicked Thoughts and Actions to them; for it is u≈øual in Scripture-phra≈øe, as to a≈øcribe all good Motions to God's Spirit, ≈øo all evil Thoughts and Actions to the Devil, not that he is the immediate Cau≈øe of them, but becau≈øe he is always ready to tempt Men to them, and one way or other to promote them.

3. I ≈øee no Rea≈øon to grant (as many have done) an immediate Power to the Devil over the fancies and imaginations of Men, and that he may know the workings of them, tho' not the ≈øecret thoughts of Mens Minds; for this ≈øeems to me to be in effect to grant him
the Knowledge of Mens Hearts, and to give him a Key to that Clo≈øet which God hath re≈øerved to him≈øelf: for it is a very nice Di≈øtinction which is here made between the Thoughts of Mens Minds, and the Images of their Fancies; and if the≈øe ≈øhould happen to be but words that ≈øignifie the ≈øame thing, we ≈øhall unawares intrench upon the Prerogative of God. Therefore becau≈øe the Scripture is a ≈øtranger to the≈øe nice and ≈øubtile di≈øtinctions between the Imaginations of the Fancy, and the Thoughts of the Heart, I think it is much ≈øafer to a≈ø≈øert the Prerogative of God in that latitude that the Scripture u≈øeth the word heart, for all the inward motions of the Mind, for the Thoughts and Intentions of the Heart, and roundly to affirm that all the inward motions of our Souls are totally exempt from the immediate cognizance of any other Spirit but God's alone; and that neither Angel nor Devil hath any further Knowledge of them, than may be collected and inferr'd in a way of probable Conjecture from the particular Knowledge of Mens Tempers and Habits and De≈øigns, and the Cour≈øe of their Actions. III. Particular; God's Knowledge of future Events. This God propo≈øes as the way to di≈øcern the true God from Idols, I≈øaiah 41.21, &c. And for this I ≈øhall only cite one Te≈øtimony of Seneca, ≈øpeaking of God's Fore-knowledge of the mo≈øt contingent things, the Di≈øpo≈øitions of Men long before they are Born; he adds, nota e≈øt enim illis operis ≈øui ≈øeries, omni√∫mque illis rerum per manus ≈øuas iturarum ≈øcientia in aperto ≈øemper e≈øt; nobis ex abdito ≈øubit; & quae repentina putamus, illis provi≈øa veniunt & familiaria; and how peremptory ≈øoever this Sect is in their di≈øputes about Fate, yet when they ≈øpeak of the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and generally in their Moral Di≈øcour≈øes, they ≈øeem plainly to me to exempt the will of Man from this fatal nece≈ø≈øity.

2. From Scripture, which gives us Te≈øtimonies and Arguments of it.

div.head: SERMON VI.Vol. VI. Of the Knowledge of God.

q.p: The Lord is a God of Knowledge.

div.p: I Have con≈øider'd this Perfection of God, in ≈øome of the greate≈øt and mo≈øt difficult in≈øtances of it, his Knowledge of the mo≈øt ≈øecret Things, the hearts of Men, and future Events; again≈øt the la≈øt of which there are ≈øome Objections, which I come now briefly to con≈øider, and pa≈øs on to what remains.

Objection the Fir≈øt; The impo≈ø≈øibility of the thing. Certainty of all Knowledge depends upon the certainty of the Object, therefore there cannot be a certain and determinate Knowledge of any thing, but what is certainly and determinately true; but future Events,
which may or may not be, have no certain and determinate Truth, that is, it is not certain either that they will or will not be, becau≈øe they have no certain Cau≈øe, therefore there can be no infallible Knowledge concerning them.
An≈øwer, This I confe≈øs is the grand Difficulty; I ≈øhall not be ≈øo ≈øolicitous to take it away, as to give ≈øatisfaction to it.

1. I might ≈øay with a very fair Probability, that the certainty of Knowledge doth not depend upon the certainty of the Cau≈øe, but of the Object, which may be certain, tho' the Cau≈øe be contingent. Which I prove thus, whatever Event hath actually happened, as becau≈øe now it is pa≈øt, it is certainly true that it was, ≈øo becau≈øe it once was, it was certainly true before it was, that it would be; as in Peter's denying of Chri≈øt. If it be now true that he hath denied him, it was true before, that he would deny him; and it being determinately true, God ≈øaw it as it was; ≈øo that here is an Object of a certain Knowledge.

2. Tho' we could not explain the po≈ø≈øibility of God's knowing future Contingencies, much le≈øs the manner how; yet we are ≈øufficiently a≈ø≈øured that God doth
know them. I will give but one in≈øtance for the Proof of this. Nothing more evident than the Sin of Adam; yet God fore-knew this; how el≈øe was Chri≈øt decreed before the Foundation of the World? Chri≈øt was a remedy upon the occa≈øion of ≈øin, now the remedy could not be de≈øigned before the ≈øin was fore≈øeen: and this being certain, cum con≈øtat de re, fru≈øtra inquiritur de modo, when we are certain of the thing, 'tis not nece≈ø≈øary to know the manner. We are ≈øatisfied of many things, the manner whereof we do not know; we believe the union of the Soul and Body, tho' no Man can explain how a Spirit can be united to Matter; we believe the continuity of matter, that is, that the parts of it hang together, of which who≈øoever ≈øaith he can give an account, doth but betray his own ignorance. And ≈øo in many other things; that Man doth not know him≈øelf, nor the mea≈øure of his own under≈øtanding, nor the nature and ob≈øcurity of things, that will not confe≈øs him≈øelf po≈øed in many things, that doth not acknowledge that there are many „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , many things the manner whereof is unimaginable, and of which our be≈øt Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding can give no account.

3. 'Tis very unrea≈øonable to expect we ≈øhould know all the ways which infinite Knowledge hath of knowing things. We have but finite Faculties and Mea≈øures, which bear no proportion to infinite Powers and Objects. Could we explain the manner how infinite Knowledge knows things, we ≈øhould be like God in Knowledge, our under≈øtandings would be infinite like his; and in this ca≈øe e≈øpecially it becomes us to put on the mode≈øty of Creatures, and to remember that we are finite and limited. Some arrogant Spirits take it for an affront to their under≈øtandings, that any one ≈øhould expect they ≈øhould believe any thing, tho' they have the highe≈øt a≈ø≈øurance of it, if they cannot explain the particular manner of it; they make nothing to deny God's Knowledge of future Events, unle≈øs they may be ≈øatisfied of the particular way how he knows them.

I know there are tho≈øe who undertake to explain the particular manner. Some ≈øay that God ≈øees future Events in ≈øpeculo voluntatis; others ≈øay that the Eternity of God is actually commen≈øurate to all Duration, as his Immen≈øity
to all Space, and ≈øo God doth not ≈øo properly fore-≈øee and fore-know, as ≈øee and know future things by the pre≈øentiality and coexi≈øtence of all things in Eternity; for they ≈øay that future things are actually pre≈øent and exi≈øting to God, tho' not in men≈øur√¢ propri√¢, yet in men≈øur√¢ alien√¢; the School-men have much more of this Jargon and canting Language; and I envy no Man the under≈øtanding the≈øe Phra≈øes, but to me they ≈øeem to ≈øignifie nothing, but to have been words invented by idle and conceited Men, which a great many ever ≈øince, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øeem to be ignorant, would ≈øeem to under≈øtand; but I wonder mo≈øt, that Men, when they have amu≈øed and puzzled them≈øelves and others with hard Words, ≈øhould call this explaining things.

The ≈øum of the An≈øwer is this; that when we have done all we can, God's fore-knowledge of future Events may ≈øeem contradictious and impo≈ø≈øible to us, much le≈øs do I expect ever to be able to give a particular account of the manner of it: but we have ≈øufficient a≈ø≈øurance of the thing, and unle≈øs we had infinite under≈øtandings, it were vanity to pretend to explain all the ways of infinite Knowledge.

Secondly, It is Objected, That if we can admit ≈øuch a Knowledge in God as ≈øeems contradictious and impo≈ø≈øible to our Rea≈øon, why may we not allow and frame ≈øuch Notions of his Goodne≈øs and Ju≈øtice?

To this I an≈øwer, There is a great difference between tho≈øe Perfections of God which are imitable, and tho≈øe which are not. Knowledge of future Events is a Perfection wherein we are not bound to be like God; and if we are a≈ø≈øured of the thing, that he doth know them, it is not nece≈ø≈øary that we ≈øhould know the manner of it, and di≈ø-intangle it from contradiction and impo≈ø≈øibility; but it is otherwi≈øe in God's Goodne≈øs and Ju≈øtice, which are imitable; he that imitates, endeavours to be like ≈øomething that he knows, and we mu≈øt have a clear Idea and Notion of that which we would bring our ≈øelves to the likene≈øs of; the≈øe Perfections of God we are capable of knowing; and therefore the Knowledge of the≈øe Perfections is chiefly recommended to us in Scripture, Jer. 9.24. By the≈øe God reveals him≈øelf, and declares his Name, and makes him≈øelf known to us, even by tho≈øe Attributes which declare his
Goodne≈øs, and Mercy, and Ju≈øtice, Exod. 34.6, 7. P≈øal. 86.15. Deut. 32.3, 4, 5. When God would give a De≈øcription of him≈øelf to Mo≈øes, he promi≈øes to cau≈øe his goodne≈øs to pa≈øs before him. So that it doth not follow, that becau≈øe God's Knowledge of future Events is to be admitted, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øeeming contradiction and impo≈ø≈øibility of it, therefore we are to admit of any Notion of God's Ju≈øtice or Goodne≈øs that ≈øeems contradictious or impo≈ø≈øible. The
Third, Objection is made up of ≈øeveral inconveniencies that would follow from God's Knowledge of future Events.

1. It would Prejudice the Liberty of the Creature. For if God have an infallible Knowledge of what we will do, then we cannot but do what he infallibly fore≈øees we will do; for otherwi≈øe his Knowledge would be fallible.

An≈øwer, God's-Fore-knowledge lays no nece≈ø≈øity upon the Event. In every Event, we may con≈øider the Effect in it ≈øelf, or with relation to the Cau≈øe, and the manner how it comes to pa≈øs; con≈øider'd in it ≈øelf, it is future, with relation to its Cau≈øes it is contingent. God ≈øees it as both, and ≈øo, as that which till it
is, may be or not be; and when it comes to pa≈øs, he ≈øees the Man do it freely; and ≈øo before it be done, it hath no nece≈ø≈øity; but upon ≈øuppo≈øition of fore-≈øight; as when it is, it hath upon ≈øuppo≈øition that it is, as Origen excellently explains it. Fore-knowledge is not the cau≈øe of the things that are fore-known; but becau≈øe the thing is future and ≈øhall be, this is the Rea≈øon why it is fore-known; for it doth not, becau≈øe it was known, come to pa≈øs; but becau≈øe it was to come to pa≈øs, therefore it was fore-known; and bare Knowledge is no more the Cau≈øe of any Event, which becau≈øe it is known mu≈øt infallibly be, than my ≈øeeing a Man run, is the Cau≈øe of his running, which, becau≈øe I do ≈øee, is infallibly ≈øo.
2ly. If God infallibly fore-knows what Men will do, how can he be ≈øerious in his Exhortations to Repentance, in his Expectation of it, and his grieving for the Impenitency of Men?

An≈øwer. All the≈øe are founded in the liberty of our Actions. God exhorts to Repentance and expects it, becau≈øe by his Grace we may do it; he is ≈øaid to grieve for our Impenitency, becau≈øe we may do otherwi≈øe, and will not. Exhortations
are not vain in them≈øelves, but very proper to their end, tho' through our ob≈øtinacy and hardne≈øs they may be rendred vain to us and without effect. If the weight of the Objection lie upon ≈øerious, and you ask how God can exhort Men ≈øeriou≈øly to that which he fore-≈øees that they will not do, tho≈øe whom he fore-knows will be finally impenitent? I an≈øwer, if his Exhortations were not ≈øerious, he could not fore≈øee the final impenitency of Men. To fore≈øee Mens final impenitency, is to fore≈øee their willful contempt of Gods Warnings and Exhortations, and Rejection of his Grace; now Mens willful contempt of his Warnings and Exhortations cannot be fore≈øeen, unle≈øs God fore≈øee that his Exhortations are ≈øerious and in good earne≈øt.
Having an≈øwer'd the Objections again≈øt God's fore-knowing future Events, I proceed to ≈øhew,

II. That God only knows future Events. I≈øa. 44.6, 7. Thus ≈øaith the Lord, the King of I≈ørael, and his Redeemer the Lord of Ho≈øts, I am the fir≈øt, and I am the la≈øt, and be≈øides me there is no God: and who, as I, ≈øhall call, and ≈øhall declare
it, and ≈øet it in order for me, ≈øince I appointed the ancient People, and the things that are coming, and ≈øhall come? let them ≈øhew unto them. I≈øa. 46.9, 10. Remember the former things of old, for I am God, and there is none el≈øe. I am God, and there is none like me, declaring the end from the beginning, and from ancient times the things that are not yet done, ≈øaying my coun≈øel ≈øhall ≈øtand, and I will do all my plea≈øure.

The Rea≈øon is evident, becau≈øe the Knowledge of future Events is beyond the reach of any finite under≈øtanding; e≈øpecially if we grant it to be beyond our finite under≈øtanding, to explain the po≈ø≈øibility of ≈øuch a Knowledge; for to be ≈øure that is out of the reach of our Knowledge, which we cannot ≈øo much as under≈øtand how it is po≈ø≈øible it ≈øhould be known by any Under≈øtanding.

But it may here be Objected; Did not the Oracles among the Heathens foretel ≈øeveral things, which Chri≈øtians are ≈øatisfied came from the Devil? I have no time at pre≈øent to examine the bu≈øine≈øs of Heathen Oracles; I could ea≈øily ≈øhew there was much impo≈øture in them: but grant they were really
delivered and given out by a Spirit; yet the darkne≈øs and ambiguity, the affected and contrived ambiguity, is ≈øuch as ≈øhews that the Devil was con≈øcious to him≈øelf of the uncertainty of his Knowledge in tho≈øe matters; and tho≈øe few that came to pa≈øs, and are in any tolerable Sen≈øe ≈øaid to be accompli≈øht, were in ≈øuch matters, either wherein prudent Conjecture might go far (and I grant the Devil to be a ≈øagacious Spirit;) or el≈øe in di≈ø-junctive Ca≈øes, as when there are but two ways for a thing to be, it mu≈øt either be ≈øo, or ≈øo, in which a bold gue≈ø≈øing may often hit right: but gue≈ø≈øing at future things, is far from a Knowledge of them, which only can clearly be made out by punctual and particular Predictions of Things, with Circum≈øtances of Time and Per≈øon, ≈øuch as we find in Scripture in many in≈øtances, to the prediction of which, the greate≈øt ≈øagacity and the utmo≈øt gue≈ø≈øing could do nothing, ≈øuch as tho≈øe Predictions of which I gave in≈øtances out of Scripture.

I have now done with the Fir≈øt general Head, I propos'd to be ≈øpoken to from the≈øe Words, viz. To prove that this
Attribute of Knowledge belongs to God. I proceed to the,
Second, viz. To con≈øider the Perfection and Prerogative of the Divine Knowledge, which I ≈øhall ≈øpeak to in the≈øe following Particulars.

1. God's Knowledge is Pre≈øent and Actual, his Eye is always open, and every thing is in the view of it. The Knowledge of the Creature is more Power than Act; it is not much that we are capable of knowing, but there is very little that we do actually know; 'tis but one thing that we can fix our Thoughts upon at once, and apply our Minds to; we can remove them to another Object, but then we mu≈øt take off our Minds from the former, and quit the actual knowledge of it: but the knowledge of God is an actual and ≈øteady Comprehen≈øion of things, he being every where pre≈øent, and all eye, nothing can e≈øcape his ≈øight, but all Objects are at once in the view of the Divine Under≈øtanding. Heb. 4.13. Neither is there any Creature that is not manife≈øt in his ≈øight: but all things are naked and opened unto the eyes of him with whom we have to do.

2. God's Knowledge is an intimate and thorough Knowledge, whereby he knows the very Nature and E≈ø≈øence of things. The Knowledge which we have of things 'tis but in part, but outward and ≈øuperficial; our Knowledge glides upon the ≈øuperficies of things, but doth not penetrate into the intimate Nature of them, it ≈øeldom reacheth further than the skin and outward appearance of things; we do not know things in their realities, but as they appear and are repre≈øented to us with all their Masks and Di≈øgui≈øes: but God knows things as they are. 1 Sam. 16.7. The Lord ≈øeeth not as Man ≈øeeth; for Man looketh on the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the Heart; God knows things throughout, all that can be known of them. The quick and piercing Eye of God Penetrates into every thing, the light of the Divine Under≈øtanding lays all things open and naked, Heb. 4.13. In which expre≈ø≈øion the Apo≈øtle alludes to the Sacrifices of Bea≈øts, which were flead and cleft down the back bone, that the Prie≈øt might look into them, and ≈øee whether they were without blemi≈øh. To the Eye of our under≈øtandings mo≈øt Objects are clo≈øe, and have their
Skins upon them: but to the Eyes of God all things are uncovered and di≈ø≈øected, and he open to his view.

3. God's Knowledge is clear and di≈øtinct. Our Under≈øtandings in the Knowledge of things are liable to great confu≈øion; we are often deceived with the near likene≈øs and re≈øemblance of things, and mi≈øtake one thing for another; our Knowledge is but a twi-light, which doth not ≈øufficiently ≈øeparate and di≈øtingui≈øh things from one another, we ≈øee things many times together and in a heap, and do but know them in gro≈øs; but there is no confu≈øion in the Divine Under≈øtanding, that is a clear Light which ≈øeparates and di≈øtingui≈øheth things of the greate≈øt nearne≈øs and re≈øemblance; God hath a particular Knowledge of the lea≈øt things, Luke 12.7. Even the very hairs of your Head are all numbred; tho≈øe things which are of the lea≈øt con≈øideration, and have the greate≈øt likene≈øs to one another, the very hairs of our Head, are ≈øeverally and di≈øtinctly known to God.

4. God's Knowledge is certain and infallible. We are ≈øubject to doubt and error in our under≈øtanding of things, every thing almo≈øt impo≈øeth upon our
Under≈øtandings, and tinctures our Minds, and makes us look on things otherwi≈øe than they are; our Temper and Complexion, our Education and Prejudice, our Intere≈øt and Advantage, our Humours and Di≈øtempers, the≈øe all mi≈ørepre≈øent things, and darken our Minds, and ≈øeduce our Judgments, and betray us to Error and Mi≈øtake: but the Divine Under≈øtanding is a clear, fixt, con≈øtant, and undi≈øturbed Light, a pure Mirrour that receives no ≈øtain from Affection, or Intere≈øt, or any other thing. Men are many times confident and apt to impo≈øe upon others, as if they were infallible: but this is the Prerogative of God, the Priviledge of the Divine Under≈øtanding, that it is ≈øecure from all po≈ø≈øibility of Errour; 'tis God only that cannot lie, Tit. 1.2. becau≈øe he cannot be deceived; the infallibility of God is the Foundation of his veracity.

5. The Knowledge of God is ea≈øie and without difficulty. We mu≈øt dig deep for Knowledge, take a great deal of pains to know a little; we do not attain the Knowledge of things without ≈øearch and ≈øtudy and great intention of Mind; we ≈øtrive to comprehend ≈øome things, but they are ≈øo va≈øt that

things, which are all infinite. Now the Under≈øtanding of God being infinite is incapable of any Addition, or Diminution, or Change. Thirdly, I come now to draw ≈øome Inferences from the ≈øeveral parts of this Di≈øcour≈øe.
I. From the Perfection of God's Knowledge.

3. This is matter of Comfort and Encouragement. He knows our wants and weakne≈øs, and will lay no more upon us than we are able to bear, for he con≈øiders that we are but Du≈øt; he knows the rage and malice of our Enemies, and can when he plea≈øes put a Hook in their No≈øe, and his Bridle in their Lips, as he did to Senacherib, 2 Kings 19.28.

2. Live as tho≈øe that believe this; be continually under the power of this Apprehen≈øion, That God takes a particular and exact notice of all thy Actions. 3. This is matter of encouragement to us in many ca≈øes. In our ≈øecret Troubles, P≈øal. 142.3. When my Spirit was overwhelmed within me, then thou knewe≈øt my path. In Ca≈øes of difficulty which

IV. From God's Knowledge of Future Events, we may learn,

1. The Vanity of A≈øtrology, and all other Arts that pretend to foretell future Events, things that depend on the Will of Free Agents. The vanity of the≈øe Arts hath been ≈øufficiently ≈øhewn by Learned Men, from the Weakne≈øs and Uncertainty of the Principles they rely upon; I ≈øhall only for

div.p:
I, AM treating of the Attributes of God; particularly of tho≈øe which relate to the Divine Under≈øtanding, his Knowledge and Wi≈ødom. The Knowledge of God only implies his bare Under≈øtanding of things, but his Wi≈ødom implies the skill of ordering and di≈øpo≈øing things to the be≈øt Ends and Purpo≈øes, the skill of making and governing

The Knowledge of God rather con≈øiders things ab≈øolutely, and in them≈øelves: The Wi≈ødom of God con≈øiders rather the Re≈øpects and Relations of Things, looks upon things under the Notion of Means, and Ends; accordingly I de≈øcribed them thus. The Knowledge of God is a Perfect comprehen≈øion of the Nature of all things, with all their Qualities, Powers, and Circum≈øtances. The Wi≈ødom of God is a perfect Comprehen≈øion of the Re≈øpects and Relations of things one to another; of their Harmony and Oppo≈øition, their fitne≈øs and unfitne≈øs to ≈øuch and ≈øuch Ends. I have largely ≈øpoken to the Fir≈øt of the≈øe; I come now to the
Second, The Wi≈ødom of God in general; together with his Maje≈øty and Soveraignty, as they are here joyned together. I begin with the
Fir≈øt, That God is the only wi≈øe God. In handling of this, I ≈øhall ≈øhew
1. In what ≈øen≈øe God may be ≈øaid to be the only wi≈øe God.
2. Prove that this Attribute belongs to God.

1. In what ≈øen≈øe God may be ≈øaid to be the only wi≈øe God. For an≈øwer to this, we may take Notice, that there are ≈øome Perfections of God that are incommunicable to the Creatures; as his Independency and Eternity.
