of him, Rom. 1.21, 23. When they knew God, they glorified him not as God, but became vain in their imaginations. And changed the glory of the incorruptible God into an image made like to corruptible man, and to birds and four-footed bea≈øts, and creeping things. Hereby they denyed the glorious Excellency of the Divine Nature; that is, that he is a Spirit, and ≈øo incapable of being repre≈øented by any material or ≈øen≈øible Image.
Secondly, I come now to ≈øpeak of the Soveraignty and Dominion of God. In which I ≈øhall ≈øhew,

Fir≈øt. What we are to under≈øtand by the Soveraignty and Dominion of God. By the≈øe we mean the full and ab≈øolute Right and Title and Authority which God hath to, and over all his Creatures, as his Creatures, and made by him. And this Right re≈øults from the Effects of that Goodne≈øs, and Power, and Wi≈ødom whereby all things are and were made; from whence there doth accrew to God a Soveraign Right and Title to all his Creatures, and a full and ab≈øolute Authority over them; that is ≈øuch a Right and Authority which doth not depend upon any Superior, nor is ≈øubject and accountable
to any for any thing that he does to any of his Creatures. And this is that which is call'd ≈øummum imperium, becau≈øe there is no power above it to check or control it, and therefore there can be none greater than this. And it is ab≈øolute, becau≈øe all the Creatures have what they have from God, and all depend upon his Goodne≈øs, and therefore they owe all po≈ø≈øible Duty and perpetual Subjection ≈øo long as they continue in Being, becau≈øe it is ≈øolely by his Power and Goodne≈øs that they continue; and therefore whatever Right or Title any one can pretend to any Per≈øon or Thing, that God hath to all things, in Deo omnes tituli omnia jura concurrunt.

So that Soveraignty and Dominion ≈øignifies a full Right and Title and Propriety in all his Creatures, and an ab≈øolute Authority over them, to govern them and di≈øpo≈øe of them, and deal with them in any way he plea≈øeth, that is not contrary to his e≈ø≈øential Dignity and Perfection, or repugnant to the Natural State and Condition of the Creature.

And for our better under≈øtanding of this, and the preventing of Mi≈øtakes which Men are apt to fall into about the Soveraignty of God, I will ≈øhew,
I. Wherein it doth not con≈øi≈øt. And,
II. Wherein it doth con≈øi≈øt.
I. Wherein it doth not con≈øi≈øt.

1. Not in a Right to gratifie and delight him≈øelf in the extreme Mi≈øery of innocent and unde≈øerving Creatures; I ≈øay, not in a right; for the right that God hath in his Creatures is founded in the Benefits he hath conferred upon them, and the Obligation they have to him upon that account. Now there's none, who becau≈øe he hath done a Benefit, can have, by vertue of that, a right to do a greater Evil than the Good which he hath done amounts to; and I think it next to madne≈øs, to doubt whether extreme and Eternal Mi≈øery be not a greater Evil, than ≈øimple Being is a Good. I know they call it phy≈øical goodne≈øs; but I do not under≈øtand how any thing is the better for being call'd by a hard Name. For what can there be that is good or de≈øirable in Being, when it only ≈øerves to be a foundation of the greate≈øt and mo≈øt la≈øting Mi≈øery? and we may ≈øafely ≈øay, that the ju≈øt God will never challenge more than an equitable right. God doth not claim any ≈øuch ≈øoveraignty to him≈øelf, as to cru≈øh and oppre≈øs innocent Creatures
without a cau≈øe, and to make them mi≈øerable without a provocation. And becau≈øe it ≈øeems ≈øome have been very apt to entertain ≈øuch groundle≈øs Jealou≈øies and unworthy Thoughts of God, he hath given us his Oath to a≈ø≈øure us of the contrary. As I live, ≈øaith the Lord, I have no plea≈øure in the death of a ≈øinner, but rather that he ≈øhould turn and live. So far is he from taking Plea≈øure in the mi≈øery and ruin of innocent Creatures, that in ca≈øe of ≈øin and provocation, he would be much rather plea≈øed, if ≈øinners would, by Repentance, avoid and e≈øcape his Ju≈øtice, than that they ≈øhould fall under it. The good God cannot be glorified or plea≈øed in doing Evil to any, where Ju≈øtice doth not require it; nothing is further from infinite Goodne≈øs than to rejoice in Evil. We account him a Tyrant and a Mon≈øter of Men, and of a devili≈øh temper, that can do ≈øo; and we cannot do a greater Injury to the good God, than to paint him out after ≈øuch a horrid and deformed manner.

2. The ≈øoveraignty of God doth not con≈øi≈øt in impo≈øing Laws upon his Creatures, which are impo≈ø≈øible either to be under≈øtood or ob≈øerved by them. For
this would not only be contrary to the dignity of the Divine Nature, but contradict the nature of a rea≈øonable Creature, which, in rea≈øon, cannot be obliged by any Power to impo≈ø≈øibilities.

3. The ≈øoveraignty of God doth not con≈øi≈øt in a liberty to tempt Men to Evil, or by any inevitable Decree to nece≈ø≈øitate them to ≈øin, or effectually to procure the ≈øins of Men, and to puni≈øh them for them. For as this would be contrary to the Holine≈øs, and Ju≈øtice, and Goodne≈øs of God; ≈øo to the nature of a rea≈øonable Creature, who cannot be guilty or de≈øerve Puni≈øhment for what it cannot help. And men cannot ea≈øily have a blacker thought of God, than to imagin that he hath, from all Eternity, carried on a ≈øecret De≈øign to circumvent the greate≈øt part of men into de≈øtruction, and underhand to draw Men into a Plot again≈øt Heaven, that by this unworthy practice he may rai≈øe a Revenue of glory to his Ju≈øtice. There's no generous and good man, but would ≈øpit in that man's Face that ≈øhould charge him with ≈øuch a De≈øign: and if they who are but very drops of goodne≈øs, in compari≈øon of God, the infinite Ocean of Goodne≈øs, would take it
for ≈øuch a Reproach; ≈øhall we attribute that to the be≈øt Being in the World, which we would dete≈øt and abominate in our ≈øelves?
II. Wherein the Soveraignty of God doth con≈øi≈øt.
1. In a right to di≈øpo≈øe of, and deal with his Creatures in any way that doth not contradict the E≈ø≈øential Perfections of God, and the natural Condition of the Creature.

2. In a right to impo≈øe what Laws he plea≈øeth upon his Creatures, whether natural and rea≈øonable; or po≈øitive, of Tryal of Obedience, provided they contradict not the Nature of God or of the Creature.
3. In a right to inflict due and de≈øerved Puni≈øhment in ca≈øe of provocation.

4. In a right to afflict any of his Creatures, ≈øo the Evil he inflicts be ≈øhort of the Benefits he hath conferred on them; yea, and farther, in a right when he plea≈øeth to annihilate the Creature, and turn it out of Being, if it ≈øhould ≈øo ≈øeem good to him, tho' that Creature have not offended him; becau≈øe what he gave was his own, and he may without injury take it away again when he plea≈øeth. In the≈øe
the Soveraignty of God con≈øi≈øts, and if there be any thing el≈øe that can be reconciled with the e≈ø≈øential Perfections of God.

Secondly, For the Proof and Confirmation of this. This is univer≈øally acknowledg'd by the Heathens, that God is the Lord and Soveraign of the World, and of all Creatures. Hence Plato calls him „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ; and Tully, omnium rerum Dominum, Lord of all; and this the Scripture doth every where attribute to him, calling him Lord of all, King of Kings, and Lord of Lords; to which we may refer all tho≈øe Doxologies, in which Power, and Dominion, and Authority are a≈øcribed to God. I will only mention that eminent Confe≈ø≈øion of Nebuchadnezzar a great King, who, when his Under≈øtanding came to him, was forced to acknowledge that God was the mo≈øt high, Dan. 4.34, 35. I infer,

Fir≈øt, Negatively, we cannot, from the ≈øoveraignty of God, infer a right to do any thing that is un≈øuitable to the Perfection of his Nature; and con≈øequently that we are to re≈øt ≈øatisfied with ≈øuch a Notion of Dominion and Soveraignty in God, as doth not plainly
and directly contradict all the Notions that we have of Ju≈øtice and Goodne≈øs: nay it would be little le≈øs than a horrid and dreadful Bla≈øphemy, to ≈øay that God can, out of his Soveraign Will and Plea≈øure, do any thing that contradicts the Nature of God, and the e≈ø≈øential Perfections of the Deity; or to imagin that the Plea≈øure and Will of the Holy, and Ju≈øt, and Good God is not always regulated and determined by the e≈ø≈øential and indi≈øpen≈øable Laws of Goodne≈øs, and Holine≈øs, and Righteou≈øne≈øs.
Secondly, Po≈øitively; we may infer from the Soveraignty and Dominion of God,
1. That we ought to own and acknowledge God for our Lord and Soveraign, who by creating us, and giving us all that we have, did create to him≈øelf a Right in us.

2. That we owe to him the utmo≈øt po≈ø≈øibility of our Love, to love him with all our hearts, and ≈øouls, and ≈øtrength; becau≈øe the Souls that we have he gave us; and that we are in a capacity to love him, is his Gift; and when we render the≈øe to him, we do but give him of his own.

3. We owe to him all imaginable ≈øubjection, and ob≈øervance, and obedience; and are with all diligence, to the utmo≈øt of our endeavours, to conform our ≈øelves to his Will, and to tho≈øe Laws which he hath impo≈øed upon us.

4. In ca≈øe of Offence and Di≈øobedience, we are without murmuring, to ≈øubmit to what he ≈øhall inflict upon us, to accept of the puni≈øhment of our iniquity, and patiently to bear the indignation of the Lord, becau≈øe we have ≈øinned again≈øt him, who is our Lord and Soveraign.

div.head: SERMON VIII.Vol. VI. The Wi≈ødom of God, in the Creation of the World.

q.p: O Lord; how manifold are thy Works! in Wi≈ødom ha≈øt thou made them all.

div.p:
I Am treating of the Attributes and Properties of God, particularly tho≈øe which relate to the Divine Under≈øtanding, which I told you are his Knowledge and Wi≈ødom. I have fini≈øht the fir≈øt, the Knowledge of God. The la≈øt Day I ≈øpake concerning the Wi≈ødom of God in general; but there are Three eminent Arguments, and famous In≈øtances of God's Wi≈ødom, which I have re≈øerved for a more large and particular handling. The Wi≈ødom of God ≈øhines forth in the Creation of the World, in the Government of it, and in the Redemption
of Mankind by Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Of the≈øe Three I ≈øhall ≈øpeak ≈øeverally.

I begin with the Fir≈øt, the Argument of God's Wi≈ødom, which the Creation doth furni≈øh us withal. In this vi≈øible frame of the World which we behold with our Eyes, which way ≈øoever we look, we are encountred with ocular demon≈øtrations of the Wi≈ødom of God. What the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith of the Power of God is true likewi≈øe of his Wi≈ødom, Rom. 1.20. The invi≈øible things of him from the creation of the world are clearly ≈øeen, being under≈øtood by the things that are made, even his eternal power and God-head: ≈øo the eternal wi≈ødom of God is under≈øtood by the things which are made. Now the Creation is an Argument of the wi≈ødom of God, as it is an effect of admirable Coun≈øel and Wi≈ødom. As any curious Work, or rare Engine doth argue the Wit of the Artificer; ≈øo the variety, and order, and regularity, and fitne≈øs of the Works of God, argue the infinite wi≈ødom of him who made them; a Work ≈øo beautiful and magnificent, ≈øuch a ≈øtately Pile as Heaven and Earth is, ≈øo curious in the ≈øeveral pieces of it, ≈øo harmonious in all its parts, every part ≈øo fitted to the ≈øervice of the whole, and each
part for the ≈øervice of another; is not this a plain Argument that there was infinite wi≈ødom in the contrivance of this Frame?

Now I ≈øhall endeavour to prove to you that this Frame of Things which we ≈øee with our Eyes, which we call the World, or the Creation, is contrived after the be≈øt manner, and hath upon it evident impre≈ø≈øions of Coun≈øel and Wi≈ødom. I grant the wi≈ødom of God is Infinite, and that many of the Ends and De≈øigns of his wi≈ødom are un≈øearchable, and pa≈øt finding out, both in the Works of Creation and Providence; and that tho' a Wi≈øe man ≈øeek to find out the work of God from the beginning to the end, he ≈øhall not be able to do it; and we ≈øhall never be able to exhau≈øt all the various Wi≈ødom and Contrivance which is in the Works of God; tho' the oftner and the nearer we meditate upon them, the more we ≈øhall ≈øee to admire in them; the more we ≈øtudy this Book of the Creation, the more we ≈øhall be a≈øtoni≈øh'd at the Wi≈ødom of the Author: but this doth not hinder but that we may di≈øcover ≈øomething of the Wi≈ødom of God, tho' it be Infinite. As the Effects of Infinite Power may fall under our
Sen≈øes, ≈øo the De≈øigns of Infinite Wi≈ødom may fall under our Rea≈øon and ∆≤nder≈øtanding; and when things appear to our be≈øt Rea≈øon, plainly to be order'd for the be≈øt, and the greate≈øt advantages of the World and Mankind, ≈øo far as we are able to judge; and if they had been otherwi≈øe, as they might have been a hundred thou≈øand ways, they would not have been ≈øo well; we ought to conclude, that things are thus, and not otherwi≈øe, is the re≈øult of Wi≈ødom.

Now the Wi≈ødom of God in the Creation will appear by con≈øidering the Works of God. Tho≈øe who have ≈øtudied Nature can di≈øcour≈øe the≈øe things more exactly and particularly. It would require perfect skill in A≈øtronomy, to declare the motions and order of Heavenly Bodies; and in Anatomy, to read Lectures of the rare contrivance of the Bodies of living Creatures. But this, as it is beyond my ability, ≈øo it would probably be above mo≈øt of your Capacities; therefore I ≈øhall content my ≈øelf with ≈øome general and more obvious in≈øtances of the Divine Wi≈ødom, which ≈øhine forth ≈øo clear in his Works, that he that runs may read it.
1. I ≈øhall take a ≈øhort ≈øurvey of the ≈øeveral parts of the World.
2. Single out Man the Ma≈øter-piece of the vi≈øible Creation.

1. If we ≈øurvey the World, and travel over the ≈øeveral parts of it in our thoughts, we ≈øhall find that all things in it are made with the greate≈øt exactne≈øs, ranged in the mo≈øt beautiful order, and ≈øerve the wi≈øe≈øt and be≈øt Ends.

If we look up to Heaven, and take notice only there of that which is mo≈øt vi≈øible, the Sun; you ≈øee how by the wi≈øe order and con≈øtancy of its cour≈øe it makes Day and Night, Winter and Summer. This the P≈øalmi≈øt takes notice of, P≈øal. 19.1, 2. The heavens declare the glory of God; and the firmament ≈øheweth his handy work. Day unto Day uttereth ≈øpeech, and night unto night ≈øheweth knowledge. It may ea≈øily be imagin'd many ways, how the Sun might have had another Cour≈øe in reference to the Earth; but no Man can devi≈øe any other that ≈øhould not be very much to the prejudice of the World; ≈øo that this being the be≈øt, it is an Argument that Wi≈ødom had the ordering and di≈øpo≈øing of it.

If we look down to the Earth, we ≈øhall ≈øee God's a≈øcending and de≈øcending; I mean clear repre≈øentations of Divine Wi≈ødom in the Trea≈øures that are hid in the Bowels of it, and tho≈øe Fruits that grow upon the ≈øurface of it. What va≈øt Heaps, and what variety of u≈øeful Materials and Minerals are ≈øcatter'd up and down in the Earth, as one would think, with a carele≈øs Hand, but yet ≈øo wi≈øely di≈øper≈øt, as is mo≈øt proper for the Nece≈ø≈øities and U≈øes of ≈øeveral Countries! Look upon the ≈øurface of the Earth, and you ≈øhall find it cloathed and adorned with Plants of a various and admirable Frame, and Beauty, and U≈øefulne≈øs. Look upon the va≈øt Ocean, and there you may ≈øee the Wi≈ødom of God in bridling and re≈øtraining that unruly Element, I mean in ≈øinking it below the Earth; whereas the Water might have been above and cover'd the Earth, and then the Earth had been in a great mea≈øure u≈øele≈øs, and incapable of tho≈øe Inhabitants which now po≈ø≈øe≈øs it.

Look again upon the Earth, and in the Air, and Sea, and you ≈øhall find all the≈øe inhabited and furni≈øht with great ≈øtore of living Creatures of ≈øeveral kinds,
wonderfully made in the frame of their Bodies, endowed with ≈øtrong inclination to increa≈øe their kinds, and with a natural Affection and Care toward their Young ones; and every kind of the≈øe Creatures armed either with ≈øtrength or wit to oppo≈øe their Enemy, or ≈øwiftne≈øs to flie from him, or ≈øtrong Holds to ≈øecure them≈øelves. But the Creation is a va≈øt Field, in which we may ea≈øily lo≈øe our ≈øelves. I ≈øhall therefore call home our wandring Thoughts; for we need not go out of our ≈øelves for a proof of Divine Wi≈ødom. I ≈øhall therefore,

2. Select the choice≈øt piece of it, Man, who is the top and perfection of this vi≈øible World. What is ≈øaid of the Elephant, or Behemoth, Job 40.19. in re≈øpect of the va≈øt bigne≈øs and ≈øtrength of his Body, is only ab≈øolutely true of Man, that he is divini opificii caput, the chief of the ways of God, and upon Earth there is none like him. Man is Mundi utriu≈øque nexus, the bond of both Worlds, as Scaliger calls him, in whom the World of Bodies, and the World of Spirits do meet, and unite; for in re≈øpect to his Body, he is related to this vi≈øible World, and is of the Earth; but in re≈øpect of his Soul, he is allied to Heaven,
and de≈øcended from above. We have looked above us, and beneath us, and about us, upon the ≈øeveral repre≈øentations of God's Wi≈ødom, and the ≈øeveral parts of the Creation; but we have not yet con≈øider'd the be≈øt piece of the vi≈øible World, which we may ≈øpeak of, without flattery of our ≈øelves, and to the prai≈øe of our Maker. God, when he had made the World, he made man after his own Image. When he had fini≈øhed the other part of the Creation, he was plea≈øed to ≈øet up this Picture of him≈øelf in it, as a Memorial of the Workman. Now we ≈øhall a little more particularly con≈øider this piece of God's Workman≈øhip, being it is better known, and more familiar to us, as it is more excellent than the re≈øt, and con≈øequently a higher in≈øtance of the Divine Wi≈ødom. It is ob≈øerved by ≈øome, that concerning the parts of the Creation, God ≈øpeaks the word, let there be light, and let there be a firmament, and there was ≈øo: but when he comes to make Man, he doth, as it were, deliberate, and enter into con≈øultation about him; And God ≈øaid, let us make man in our image, after our likene≈øs; and let him have dominion. Gen. 1.26; as if Man, above all the re≈øt,
were the Effect and Re≈øult of Divine Wi≈ødom, and the Creature of his Coun≈øel.
Man may be con≈øider'd either in him≈øelf, and in re≈øpect of the Parts of which he con≈øi≈øts, Soul and Body; or with relation to the Univer≈øe, and other parts of the Creation.

1. Con≈øider him in him≈øelf, as compounded of Soul and Body. Con≈øider Man in his outward and wor≈øe part, and you ≈øhall find that to be admirable, even to a≈øtoni≈øhment; in re≈øpect of which, the P≈øalmi≈øt cries out, P≈øal. 139.14. I am fearfully and wonderfully made, marvellous are thy works, and that my ≈øoul knoweth right well. The frame of our Bodies is ≈øo curiou≈øly wrought, and every part of it ≈øo full of Miracle, that Galen (who was otherwi≈øe backward enough to the Belief of a God) when he had anatomized Man's Body, and carefully ≈øurvey'd the frame of it, viewed the fitne≈øs and u≈øefulne≈øs of every part of it, and the many ≈øeveral intentions of every little Vein, and Bone, and Mu≈øcle, and the beauty of the whole; he fell into a pang of Devotion, and wrote a Hymn to his Creator. And tho≈øe excellent Books of his, de u≈øu
partium, of the u≈øefulne≈øs and convenient contrivance of every part of the Body, are a mo≈øt exact demon≈øtration of the Divine Wi≈ødom, which appears in the make of our Body, of which Books, Ga≈ø≈øendus ≈øaith, the whole work is writ with a kind of Enthu≈øia≈øm. The Wi≈ødom of God, in the frame of our Bodies, very much appears by a curious con≈øideration of the ≈øeveral parts of it; but that requiring a very accurate skill in Anatomy, I chu≈øe rather wholly to forbear it, than by my unskilfulne≈øs to be injurious to the Divine Wi≈ødom.

But this domicilium corporis, this Hou≈øe of our Body, tho' it be indeed a curious piece; yet it is nothing to the noble Inhabitant that dwells in it. This Cabinet, tho' it be exqui≈øitely wrought, and very rich; yet it comes infinitely ≈øhort in value of the Jewel that is hid and laid up in it. How does the glorious faculty of Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding exalt us above the re≈øt of the Creatures! Nature hath not made that particular Provi≈øion for Man, which it hath made for other Creatures, becau≈øe it hath provided for him in general, in giving him a Mind and Rea≈øon. Man is not born cloathed, nor armed with any
con≈øiderable Weapon for defence; but he hath Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding to provide the≈øe things for him≈øelf; and this alone excells all the advantages of other Creatures; he can keep him≈øelf warmer and ≈øafer, he can fore-≈øee Dangers and provide again≈øt them; he can provide Weapons that are better than Horns, and Teeth, and Paws, and by the advantage of his Rea≈øon, is too hard for all other Creatures, and can defend him≈øelf again≈øt their Violence.

If we con≈øider the Mind of Man yet nearer, how many Arguments of Divinity are there in it! That there ≈øhould be at once in our Under≈øtandings di≈øtinct comprehen≈øions of ≈øuch variety of Objects; that it ≈øhould pa≈øs in its Thoughts from Heaven to Earth in a moment, and retain the memory of things pa≈øt, and take a pro≈øpect of the future, and look forward as far as Eternity! Becau≈øe we are familiar to our ≈øelves, we cannot be ≈øtrange and wonderful to our ≈øelves: But the great Miracle of the World is the Mind of Man, and the contrivance of it an Eminent In≈øtance of God's Wi≈ødom.

2. Con≈øider Man with relation to the Univer≈øe, and you ≈øhall find the
Wi≈ødom of God doth appear, in that all things are made ≈øo u≈øeful for Man, who was de≈øign'd to be the chief Inhabitant of this vi≈øible World, the Gue≈øt whom God de≈øign'd principally to entertain in this Hou≈øe which he built. Not that we are to think, that God hath ≈øo made all things for Man, that he hath not made them at all for him≈øelf, and po≈ø≈øibly for many other u≈øes than we can imagine; for we much over-value our ≈øelves, if we think them to be only for us; and we dimini≈øh the Wi≈ødom of God in re≈øtraining it to one end: but the chief and principal End of many things is the U≈øe and Service of Man; and in reference to this End, you ≈øhall find that God hath made abundant and wi≈øe Provi≈øion.
More particularly we will con≈øider Man.

1. In his natural capacity, as a part of the World. How many things are there in the World for the ≈øervice and plea≈øure, for the u≈øe and delight of Man, which, if Man were not in the World, would be of little u≈øe? Man is by Nature a contemplative Creature, and God has furni≈øh'd him with many Objects to exerci≈øe his Under≈øtanding
upon, which would be ≈øo far u≈øele≈øs and lo≈øt, if Man were not. Who ≈øhould ob≈øerve the Motions of the Stars, and the Cour≈øes of tho≈øe Heavenly Bodies, and all the Wonders of Nature? Who ≈øhould prie into the ≈øecret Virtues of Plants, and other natural things, if there were not, in the World, a Creature endowed with Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding? Would the Bea≈øts of the Field ≈øtudy A≈øtronomy, or turn Chymi≈øts, and try Experiments in Nature?

What variety of beautiful Plants and Flowers is there! which can be imagin'd to be of little other u≈øe but for the Plea≈øure of Man. And if Man had not been, they would have lo≈øt their grace, and been trod down by the Bea≈øts of the Field, without pity or ob≈øervation; they would not have made them into Garlands and No≈øe-gays. How many ≈øorts of Fruits are there which grow upon high Trees, out of the reach of Bea≈øts! and indeed they take no Plea≈øure in them. What would all the va≈øt bodies of Trees have ≈øerved for, if Man had not been to build with them, and make Dwellings of them? Of what u≈øe would all the Mines of Metal have been, and of Coal, and the

2. Con≈øider Man in his Geographical Capacity, as I may call it, in relation to his Habitation in this or that Climate, or Country. The Wi≈ødom of God hath ≈øo order'd Things, that the Nece≈ø≈øities of every Country are ≈øupplyed one way or other. Egypt hath no Rains; but the River Nilus overflows it, and makes it fruitful. Under the Line, where there are exce≈ø≈øive Heats, every day there are con≈øtant gales and breezes of cool Wind, to fan and refre≈øh the ≈øcorched Inhabitants. The hotter Countries are furni≈øht with Materials for Silk, a light Cloathing; we that are cooler here in England, with materials for Cloth, a warmer Cloathing; Ru≈ø≈øia and Mu≈øcovy, which are extreme Cold, are provided with warm Furs, and Skins of Bea≈øts.

3. Con≈øider Man in his capacity of Commerce and Entercour≈øe. Man is a ≈øociable Creature; be≈øides the advantages of Commerce with remoter Nations, for ≈øupplying every Country with tho≈øe
Conveniences and Commodities which each doth peculiarly afford. And here the Wi≈ødom of God does plainly appear in di≈øpo≈øing the Sea into ≈øeveral parts of the World, for the more ≈øpeedy Commerce and Entercour≈øe of ≈øeveral Nations. Now if every Country had brought forth all Commodities; that had been needle≈øs and ≈øuperfluous, becau≈øe they might have been had without Commerce; be≈øides that the great encouragement of Entercour≈øe among Nations, which is ≈øo agreeable to humane Nature, would have been taken away: If every Country had been, as now it is, de≈øtitute of many things other Countries have, and there had been no Sea to give an opportunity of Trafick; the World had been very defective as to the U≈øe of Man. Now here appears the Wi≈ødom of God, that the World, and all things in it, are contriv'd for the be≈øt.

Thus I have endeavour'd to do ≈øomething toward the di≈øplaying of God's Wi≈ødom in the workman≈øhip of the World; altho' I am very ≈øen≈øible how much I have been ma≈øter'd and oppre≈øt by the greatne≈øs and weight of ≈øo noble an Argument. For who can declare the
works of God! and who can ≈øhew forth all his prai≈øe!
The U≈øe I ≈øhall make of what has been ≈øaid, ≈øhall be in three Particulars.

1. This confutes the Epicureans, who impute the World, and this orderly and beautiful Frame of Things to Chance‚ñ™ Tho≈øe things which are the proper Effects of Coun≈øel, and bear the plain Impre≈ø≈øions of Wi≈ødom upon them, ought not to be attributed to Chance. What a madne≈øs is it to grant all things to be as well made, as if the wi≈øe≈øt Agent upon Coun≈øel and De≈øign had contriv'd them; and yet to a≈øcribe them to Chance! Now he that denies things to be ≈øo wi≈øely framed, mu≈øt pick holes in the Creation, and ≈øhew ≈øome fault and irregularity in the Frame of Things, which no Man ever yet pretended to do. Did ever any Anatomi≈øt pretend to ≈øhew how the Body of Man might have been better contriv'd, and fitter for the U≈øes of a Rea≈øonable Creature than it is; or any A≈øtronomer to rectifie the Cour≈øe of the Sun. As for the Extravagant and Bla≈øphemous Speech of Alphon≈øus, That if he had ≈øtood at God's Elbow when he made the World, he could have told him how to have made it better; be≈øides his
Pride, it ≈øhews nothing but his Ignorance; that he built his A≈øtronomy upon a fal≈øe Hypothe≈øis, as is generally believed now by the Learned in that Science; and no wonder he found fault with the World, when he mi≈øtook the Frame of it: But tho≈øe who have been mo≈øt ver≈øt in Nature, and have mo≈øt pried into the ≈øecrets of it, have mo≈øt admired the workman≈øhip both of the great World, and the le≈øs.

But if we mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe the World to be as well made as Wi≈ødom could contrive it, which is generally granted; it is a mon≈øtrous folly to impute it to Chance. A man might better ≈øay, Archimedes did not make any of his Engines by Skill, but by Chance; and might more ea≈øily maintain that Cardinal Richlieu did not manage Affairs by any Arts or Policies, but they fell out by meer Chance. What pitiful ≈øhifts is Epicurus put to, when the be≈øt Account he can give of the World, is this; That Matter always was, and the parts of it in motion, and after a great many Tryals, the parts of Matter at length hamper'd them≈øelves in this fortunate order wherein they now are; that men, at fir≈øt, grew out of the Earth, were nouri≈øht by the Navel≈øtring,
and when they were ≈øtrong enough, broke loo≈øe and weaned them≈øelves; that the No≈øtrils were made by the Waters making them≈øelves a pa≈ø≈øage out of the Body; and the Stomack and Bowels by the Waters forcing a pa≈ø≈øage downward; that the Members of the Body were not made for tho≈øe ∆≤≈øes for which they ≈øerve, but chanced to be ≈øo, and the u≈øes afterwards found out. Is it worth the while to advance ≈øuch ≈øen≈øele≈øs Opinions as the≈øe, to deny the Wi≈ødom of God? Is it not much ea≈øier, and more rea≈øonable to ≈øay, that the Wi≈ødom of God made all the≈øe things, than to trouble our ≈øelves to imagin how all things ≈øhould happen thus conveniently by Chance? Did you ever know any great work, in which there was variety of parts, and an orderly di≈øpo≈øition of them required, done by Chance, and without the direction of Wi≈ødom and Coun≈øel? How long time might a Man take to jumble a ≈øet of four and twenty Letters together, before they would fall out to be an exact Poem; yea, or make a Book of tolerable Sen≈øe, tho' but in Pro≈øe? How long might a Man ≈øprinkle Oil and Colours upon Canvas, with a carele≈øs Hand, before this would produce the exact Picture of a Man? And
is a Man ea≈øilier made by Chance, than his Picture? He that tells me that this great and curious frame of the World was made by Chance, I could much more believe him, if he ≈øhould tell me that Henry the VII's Chappel, in We≈øtmin≈øter, was not built by any mortal man, but the Stones did grow in tho≈øe forms into which they ≈øeem to us to be cut and graven; that the Stones; and Timber, and Iron, and Bra≈øs, and all the other Materials, came thither by Chance, and upon a day met all happily together, and put them≈øelves into that delicate order, in which we ≈øee them ≈øo clo≈øe compacted, that it mu≈øt be a great Chance that parts them again. Now is it not much ea≈øier to imagin how a skilful Workman ≈øhould rai≈øe a Building, than how Timber, and Stones, and how that variety of Materials which is required to a great and ≈øtately Building, ≈øhould meet together all of a ju≈øt bigne≈øs, and exactly fitted, and by chance take their places, and range them≈øelves into that order. I in≈øi≈øt the longer upon this, becau≈øe I am ≈øen≈øible how much Athei≈øm hath gained in this Age.

2. Let us Admire, and Adore, and Prai≈øe the Wi≈ødom of God, who hath e≈øtabli≈øht the world by his wi≈ødom, and ≈øtretched out the heavens by his under≈øtanding; who hath made all things in number, weight, and mea≈øure, that is, by exact wi≈ødom. The wi≈øe Works of God are the proper Object of our prai≈øe; and this is a day proper for this Work of Prai≈øe and Thanks-giving. Now under the Go≈øpel, ≈øince Chri≈øt was clearly revealed, we have new matter of Prai≈øe and Thanksgiving; but as God has given us Chri≈øt, ≈øo he hath given us our Beings. We are not ≈øo to remember our Redeemer, as to forget our Creator. The Goodne≈øs, and Power, and Wi≈ødom of God, which appears in the Creation of the World, ought ≈øtill to be matter of Admiration and Prai≈øe to Chri≈øtians. It is a great Fault and Neglect among Chri≈øtians, that they are not more taken up with the Works of God, and the Contemplation of the Wi≈ødom which ≈øhines forth in them. We are apt enough to admire other things, little Toys; but we overlook this va≈øt curious Engine of the World, and the great Artificer of all things. It was truly ≈øaid of one, that mo≈øt
men are ≈øo ≈øtupid and incon≈øiderate, as to admire the Works of a Painter or a Carver, more than the Works of God. There are many that have be≈øtowed more Eloquence in the Prai≈øe of a curious Picture, or an exact Building, than ever they did upon this noble and exqui≈øite frame of the World, or any of the works of God. We can admire the wi≈ødom, and de≈øign, and skill of petty Arti≈øts, and little Engineers; but here is wi≈ødom in the Beauty and Order of the Creation. Did we love God, and take plea≈øure in the Effects of his Wi≈ødom and Power, we ≈øhould be more in the Contemplation of them. P≈øal. 111.2. The works of the Lord are great, ≈øought out of all them that have plea≈øure therein. Let us then ≈øay with the P≈øalmi≈øt,; O Lord, how manifold are thy works! in wi≈ødom ha≈øt thou made them all; the Earth is full of thy riches, &c.

More particularly let us, with an humble thankfulne≈øs, admire the Wi≈ødom which hath made and di≈øpo≈øed all things ≈øo fitly for our U≈øe and Service, and with ≈øo merciful a re≈øpect to us; The Light and Influence of Heaven;
the Bea≈øts and the Fruits of the Earth. We find the P≈øalmi≈øt often prai≈øing God upon this Account, P≈øal. 136.4, 5. &c. The Wi≈ødom which hath framed the≈øe Bodies of ours. P≈øal. 139.14, 15, 16. Which hath endowed us with Knowledge and Under≈øtanding. Elihu complains, that Men were apt to over-look the≈øe great Ble≈ø≈øings of God, Job 35.10, 11, 12. But none ≈øaith, where is God my maker, who giveth Songs in the night? Who teacheth us more than the Bea≈øts of the earth, and maketh us wi≈øer than the Fowls of Heaven? There they cry, but none giveth an≈øwer, becau≈øe of the pride of evil men.

3. ∆≤≈øe; Tru≈øt the Wi≈ødom of God, which made the World, to govern it, and the Affairs of it; and the Wi≈ødom which hath framed thy Body in ≈øo curious and exqui≈øite a manner, and formed thy Spirit within thee, and hath made ≈øo many Creatures, with reference to thy Nece≈ø≈øity and Comfort, tru≈øt him for thy future Provi≈øion. Mat. 6.25. I ≈øay unto you, Take no thought for your lives, what ye ≈øhall eat, &c. Is not the life more than meat? and the body than rayment? He hath given us our
Souls, he hath breathed into us the breath of life, and made the≈øe Bodies without our care and thought; He hath done the greater, will he not do the le≈øs? When thou art ready anxiou≈øly and ≈øolicitou≈øly to ≈øay, what ≈øhall I do for the nece≈ø≈øaries of Life? Con≈øider whence thou did≈øt receive thy Life, who made this Body of thine; thou may≈øt be a≈ø≈øur'd that the Wi≈ødom which hath created the≈øe, con≈øider'd how to ≈øupply them; the Wi≈ødom of God knew that you would want all the≈øe, and hath accordingly provided for them, therefore fear not.

div.head: SERMON VIII.Vol. VI. The Wi≈ødom of God, in his Providence. Preached at Ken≈øington.

q.p: Ca≈øting all your care upon him, for he careth for you.

div.p:
AMONGST the ≈øeveral Duties, which towards the conclu≈øion of this Epi≈øtle the Apo≈øtle exhorts Chri≈øtians to, this is one, not to be over-much ≈øolicitous and concerned about what may befal us, but to refer our ≈øelves to the providence of God, which takes care of us. In ≈øpeaking to this Argument, I ≈øhall
I. Con≈øider the nature of the Duty here required, which is to ca≈øt our care upon God.
II. The Argument u≈øed to per≈øwade us to it; becau≈øe he careth for us.

I. For the nature of the Duty here required. The word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øignifies an anxious care about Events; a care that is accompanied with trouble and di≈øquiet of Mind about what may befall us; about the good that we hope for, and de≈øire; or about the Evil which we fear may come upon us. This the Apo≈øtle exhorts us to throw off; and to leave to the Providence of God and his Care, all tho≈øe Events which we are apt to be ≈øo ≈øolicitous and di≈øquieted about. The Expre≈ø≈øion ≈øeems to be taken out of P≈øal. 55.22. ca≈øt thy burthen upon the Lord, and he ≈øhall ≈øu≈øtain thee.
Now that we may not mi≈øtake our Duty in this matter, I ≈øhall ≈øhew what is not here meant by ca≈øting all our care upon God, and then what is meant by it.

The Apo≈øtle doth not hereby intend to take Men off from a provident care and diligence, about the concernments of this life; this is not only contrary to Rea≈øon, but to many expre≈øs Precepts and Pa≈ø≈øages of Scripture, wherein Diligence is recommended to us, and the
Ble≈ø≈øing of God, and the good Succe≈øs of our Affairs promi≈øed thereto; wherein we are commanded to provide for tho≈øe of our Family, which cannot be done without ≈øome ≈øort of care; and wherein Sloathfulne≈øs and Negligence are condemned, and threatned with Poverty; ≈øo that this is not to ca≈øt our care upon God, to take no care of our ≈øelves, to u≈øe no diligence and endeavour for the obtaining of the Good which we de≈øire, and the prevention of the Evil we fear; this is to tempt the Providence of God, and to ca≈øt that Burthen upon him, which he expects we ≈øhould bear our ≈øelves.
But by ca≈øting our care upon God, the Apo≈øtle intends the≈øe two things.

1. That after all prudent Care and Diligence have been u≈øed by us, we ≈øhould not be farther ≈øolicitous, nor trouble our ≈øelves about the event of Things, which, when we have done all we can, will be out of our power. And this certainly is our Saviour's meaning, when he bids us, take no care for the morrow. When we have done what is fit for us for the pre≈øent to do, we ≈øhould not di≈øquiet and torment our ≈øelves about the I≈ø≈øue and Event of Things.

2. Ca≈øting our care upon God, implies, that we ≈øhould refer the i≈ø≈øue of Things to his Providence, which is continually vigilant over us, and knows how to di≈øpo≈øe all things to the be≈øt, entirely confiding in his Wi≈ødom and Goodne≈øs, that he will order all things for our good, and in that confidence, re≈øolving to re≈øt ≈øatisfied and contented with the di≈øpo≈øals of his Providence, whatever they be.

You ≈øee then the nature of the Duty which the Apo≈øtle here exhorts to, viz. That after all prudent Care and Diligence have been u≈øed on our parts, we ≈øhould not be di≈øquieted in our Minds about the event of things, but leave them to God, who hath the Care of us and of all our Concernments. Which is the

II. Thing I propo≈øed to ≈øpeak to, and which I intend chiefly to in≈øi≈øt upon, viz. The Argument which the Apo≈øtle here u≈øeth to per≈øwade us to this Duty, of ca≈øting all our care upon God; becau≈øe it is he that careth for us; and this implies in it the≈øe two things.
1. In general, That the Providence of God governs the World, and concerns it ≈øelf in the Affairs of Men, and di≈øpo≈øeth of all Events that happen to us.

2. More particularly, That this Providence is peculiarly concerned for good Men, and that he takes a ≈øpecial care of them and their Concerns; He careth for you. The Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaks this to them, not only as Men, but as Chri≈øtians. And thus the P≈øalmi≈øt, from whom the≈øe words ≈øeem to be taken, does apply and limit this Promi≈øe; Ca≈øt thy burthen upon the Lord, and he ≈øhall ≈øu≈øtain thee; he ≈øhall never ≈øuffer the righteous to be moved.

1. That God taketh care of us, implies in general, That the Providence of God governs the World, and concerns it ≈øelf in the Affairs of Men, and di≈øpo≈øeth of all Events that happen to us. I ≈øhall not now enter upon a large Proof of the Providence of God; that is too large and intricate an Argument for a ≈øhort Di≈øcour≈øe, and hath a great deal of nicety and difficulty in it; and tho' it be a fundamental Principle of Religion, and hath been almo≈øt generally entertained and believed by Mankind, and that upon very good Rea≈øon; yet becau≈øe the vindication of many particular appearances of Providence, does in a great mea≈øure depend upon a full view and comprehen≈øion of the
whole de≈øign, therefore we mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily refer our ≈øelves, for full ≈øati≈øfaction, as to ≈øeveral difficulties and Objections, to the other World, when we ≈øhall ≈øee God's works, together with the relation of every part to the whole de≈øign, and then many particular Pa≈ø≈øages, which may now ≈øeem odd and crooked, as we look upon them by them≈øelves, will in Relation to the whole, appear to have a great deal of Rea≈øon and Regularity in them.

Therefore I ≈øhall at pre≈øent only briefly, and in the general, ≈øhew that it is very credible, that there is a wi≈øe Providence, that governs the World, and intere≈øts it ≈øelf in the affairs of Men, and di≈øpo≈øeth of all Events which happen to us.

And I de≈øire it may be ob≈øerved in the entrance upon this Argument, that the handling of this Que≈øtion concerning Providence, doth ≈øuppo≈øe the Being of God, and that he made the World, as Principles already known and granted, before we come to di≈øpute of his Providence; for it would be in vain, to argue about the Providence of God, with tho≈øe who que≈øtion his Being, and
whether the World was made by him: But ≈øuppo≈øing the≈øe two Principles, that God is, and that he made the World, it is very credible, that he ≈øhould take care of the Government of it, and e≈øpecially of one of the noble≈øt Parts of it, the race of Mankind. For we cannot believe, that he who employed ≈øo much Power and Wi≈ødom, in the rai≈øing of this great and magnificent Pile, and furni≈øhing every part of it with ≈øuch variety of Creatures, ≈øo exqui≈øitely and ≈øo wi≈øely fitted for the u≈øe and ≈øervice of one another, ≈øhould ≈øo ≈øoon as he had perfected it, for≈øake his own Workman≈øhip, and take no farther care of it; E≈øpecially con≈øidering that it is no trouble and di≈øquiet to him, either to take notice of what is done here below, or to interpo≈øe for the regulating of any Di≈øorders that may happen; for Infinite Knowledge, and Wi≈ødom, and Power can do this with all imaginable ea≈øe, knows all things, and can do all things, without any di≈øturbance of its own happine≈øs.

And this hath always been the common Apprehen≈øion of Mankind, that God knows all things, and ob≈øerves every thing that is done in the World,
and when he plea≈øeth, interpo≈øes in the affairs of it. 'Tis true indeed the Epicureans did deny that God either made the World, or governs it; and therefore wi≈øe Men always doubted whether they did indeed believe the Being of God, or not; but being unwilling to incur the danger of ≈øo odious an Opinion, they were content for fa≈øhion ≈øake, to own his Being, provided they might take away the be≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øub≈øtantial Arguments for the proof o ‚Ä¢ it. The re≈øt of the Philo≈øophers owned a Providence, at lea≈øt a general Providence, that took care of great and more important Matters, but did not de≈øcend to a con≈øtant and particular care of every Per≈øon, and every little Event belonging to them. Interdum curio≈øus ≈øingulorum, ≈øays Tully; now and then, when he plea≈øes, he takes care of particular Per≈øons, and their le≈ø≈øer concernments; but many of them thought, that God did generally neglect the ≈ømaller and more incon≈øiderable affairs of the World, Dii minora negligunt, neque agello ‚Ä¢ ≈øingulorum & viticulas per≈øequuntur, The Gods overlook ≈ømaller matters, and do not mind every Mans little Field and Vine. Such imperfect apprehen≈øions had they
of the Providence of God. And tho' they would ≈øeem hereby to con≈øult the Dignity and ea≈øe of the Deity, by exempting him from the care and trouble of le≈ø≈øer Matters, yet in truth and reality, they ca≈øt a di≈øhonourable reflection upon him, as if it were a burthen to Infinite Knowledge, and Power, and Goodne≈øs, to take care of every thing.

But now Divine Revelation hath put this matter out of doubt, by a≈ø≈øuring us of God's particular care of all Per≈øons and Events. Our Saviour tells us, that God's Providence extends to the lea≈øt and mo≈øt incon≈øiderable Creatures, to the gra≈øs of the Field, which to day is, and to morrow is ca≈øt into the Oven, Mat. 6.30. To the fowls of the air, and that to the lea≈øt of them, even to the Sparrows, two of which are ≈øold for a Farthing, and yet not one of them falleth to the ground without God, Mat. 10.29. Much more doth the Providence of God extend to Men, which are Creatures far more con≈øiderable, and to the very lea≈øt thing that belongs to us, to the very hairs of our head, which are all numbered, the lowe≈øt in≈øtance that can be thought on.

So that the light of Nature owns a more general Providence; and Divine Revelation hath rectified tho≈øe imperfect apprehen≈øions which Men had about it, and hath ≈øatisfied us, that it extends it ≈øelf to all particulars, and even to the lea≈øt things and mo≈øt incon≈øiderable. And this is no ways incredible, con≈øidering the Infinite Perfection of the Divine Nature, in re≈øpect of which, God can with as much and greater ea≈øe, take care of every thing, than we can do of any one thing; and the belief of this is the great foundation of Religion. Men therefore pray to God for the good they want, and to be freed from the evils they fear, becau≈øe they believe that he always regards and hears them. Men therefore make Con≈øcience of their Duty, becau≈øe they believe God ob≈øerves them, and will reward and puni≈øh their good and evil Deeds. So that take away the Providence of God, and we pull down one of the main Pillars upon which Religion ≈øtands, we rob our ≈øelves of one of the greate≈øt Comforts and be≈øt Refuges in the Afflictions and Calamities of this life, and of all our hopes of happine≈øs in the next.

And tho' there be many di≈øorders in the World, e≈øpecially in the Affairs of Men, the mo≈øt irregular and intractable Piece of God's Creation; yet this is far from being a ≈øufficient Objection again≈øt the Providence of God, if we con≈øider, that God made Man a free Creature, and capable of abu≈øing his Liberty, and intends this pre≈øent life for a ≈øtate of trial in order to another, where Men ≈øhall receive the ju≈øt recompence of their Actions here: And then if we con≈øider, that many of the evils and di≈øorders, which God permits to happen, are capable of being over-ruled by him to a greater good, and are made many times to ≈øerve wi≈øe and excellent purpo≈øes, and that the Providence of God does ≈øometimes vi≈øibly and remarkably interpo≈øe, for the prevention and remedy of great Di≈øorders and Confu≈øions; I ≈øay con≈øidering all this, it is no blemi≈øh to the Divine Providence, to permit many of tho≈øe Irregularities which are in the World, and ≈øuffer the Fates of good and bad Men to be ≈øo cro≈øs and unequal in this life. For ≈øuppo≈øing another life after this, wherein Men ≈øhall come to an Account, and every Man ≈øhall receive
the ju≈øt recompence of his Actions, there will then be a proper Sea≈øon and full Opportunity, of ≈øeting all things ≈øtreight, and no Man ≈øhall have rea≈øon then, either to glory in his wickedne≈øs, or to complain of his ≈øufferings in this World. This is the fir≈øt, that God's Providence governs the World, and intere≈øts it ≈øelf in the affairs of Men, and di≈øpo≈øeth of all Events that happens to them; and this is a very good Rea≈øon, why we ≈øhould ca≈øt our particular cares upon him, who hath undertaken the Government of the whole.

2. The Providence of God is more peculiarly concerned for good Men, and he takes a more particular and e≈øpecial care of them. The Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaks this to Chri≈øtians, ca≈øt all your care on him, for he careth for you. And this David limits in a more peculiar manner to good Men; ca≈øt thy burthen upon the Lord, and he will ≈øu≈øtain thee, he ≈øhall never ≈øuffer the righteous to be moved.

The Providence of God many times pre≈øerves good Men from tho≈øe Evils which happen to others, and by a peculiar and remarkable interpo≈øition, re≈øcues them out of tho≈øe Calamities which it ≈øuffers others to fall into;
and God many times ble≈ø≈øeth good Men, with remarkable pro≈øperity and ≈øucce≈øs in their Affairs. To which purpo≈øe there are innumerable Declarations and Promi≈øes in the Holy Scriptures, ≈øo well known that I ≈øhall not trouble you with the recital of them.

II. By inquiring more particularly into the nature of this De≈øign, and the Means how it is accompli≈øht. II. Let us now enquire what Means the Wi≈ødom of God u≈øeth for our recovery. For opening of this, we will con≈øider,
1. The fitne≈øs of the Per≈øon de≈øigned for this Work.
2. The fitne≈øs of the Means whereby he was to accompli≈øh it.

1. The fitne≈øs of the Per≈øon de≈øign'd for this Work; and that was the eternal Son of God, who in re≈øpect of his Infinite Wi≈ødom and Power, the Dignity and Credit of his Per≈øon, his dearne≈øs to his Father, and Intere≈øt in him, was very fit to undertake this Work, to mediate a Reconciliation between God and Man.

2. The fitne≈øs of the Means whereby he was to accompli≈øh it; and the≈øe I ≈øhall refer to two Heads, his Humiliation and Exaltation. All the Parts of the≈øe are very ≈øub≈øervient to the De≈øign of our Redemption.
I. The Humiliation of Chri≈øt, which con≈øi≈øts of three principal Parts; his Incarnation, his Life, and his Death.

1. His Incarnation, which is ≈øet forth in Scripture by ≈øeveral Expre≈ø≈øions; his being made fle≈øh, and dwelling among us, John 1.14. In general, this made him a fit Mediator, an equal and middle Per≈øon to interpo≈øe in this Difference, and take up this Quarrel between God and Man. Being both God and man, he was concerned for both Parties, and intere≈øted both in the Honour of God, and the

More particularly, his Incarnation did fit him for tho≈øe two Offices which he was to perform in his Humiliation, of Prophet and Prie≈øt.
1. The Office of Prophet, to teach us both by his Doctrine and his Life.

By his Doctrine. His being in the likene≈øs of Man, this made him more familiar to us. 2. For the Office of Prie≈øt. He was fit to be our Prie≈øt, becau≈øe he was taken from among Men, as the Apo≈øtle
≈øpeaks; fit to ≈øuffer as being, Man having a body prepared, as it is Heb. 10.5. and fit to ≈øatisfie by his ≈øufferings for the Sins of all Men, as being God, which put an infinite Dignity and Value upon them, the ≈øufferings of an infinite Per≈øon being equal to the offences done again≈øt an Infinite God. 2. His Life was a means admirably fitted to bring Men to Holine≈øs and Goodne≈øs. I might go through all the parts of it, but becau≈øe I intend to be very ≈øhort upon the≈øe Heads, I ≈øhall only take notice of that Part of his Life, which was ≈øpent in his publick Mini≈øtry; he went about doing good; the Doctrine that he Preached was Calculated for the de≈øtroying of Sin, and the promoting of Holine≈øs; the great End

I know the ≈øufferings of Chri≈øt were, by the wi≈øe of the World, made the great Objection again≈øt the Wi≈ødom of this di≈øpen≈øation; the Cro≈øs of Chri≈øt was to the Greeks fooli≈øhne≈øs: and yet the wi≈øe≈øt of them had determined otherwi≈øe in general, tho' not in this particular Ca≈øe. Fir≈øt, The unrea≈øonablene≈øs of Unbelief. I. The de≈øign of the Go≈øpel is rea≈øonable, and gratifies our Under≈øtandings. And in this re≈øpect the Go≈øpel hath incomparable Advantages above any other Religion. The end of all Religion is to advance Piety and Holine≈øs, and real Goodne≈øs among Men;

1. It repre≈øents the Perfections of God to the greate≈øt advantage, e≈øpecially tho≈øe which tend mo≈øt to the promotion of Piety, and the love of God in us; his Ju≈øtice and Mercy.

(1.) His Ju≈øtice. The Go≈øpel repre≈øents it inflexible in its Rights, and inexorable, and that will not in any ca≈øe let Sin go unpuni≈øh'd. The impartiality of the Divine Ju≈øtice appears in this Di≈øpen≈øation, that when God pardons the Sinner, yet he will puni≈øh Sin ≈øo ≈øeverely in his own Son who was the Surety. Now what could more tend to di≈øcountenance Sin, and convince us of the great evil of it?

(2.) His Mercy. This Di≈øpen≈øation is a great demon≈øtration of the Mercy, and Goodne≈øs, and Love of God, in ≈øending his Son to die for Sinners, and in ≈øaving us by devoting and ≈øacrificing him, John 3.16. For God ≈øo loved
the world, that he gave his only begotten Son. Rom. 5.8. But God commendeth his love towards us, in that while we were yet Sinners, Chri≈øt died for us. 1 John 4.9, 10. In this was manife≈øted the love of God towards us, becau≈øe God ≈øent his only begotten Son into the world, that we might live through him. Herein is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and ≈øent his Son to be the propitiation for our ≈øins. Now this repre≈øentation of God's Mercy and Love which the Go≈øpel makes, is of great force and efficacy to melt our Hearts into love to God.

2. The Second Argument to Piety is fear of Puni≈øhment. The Go≈øpel hath revealed to us the mi≈øery of tho≈øe who continue in their Sin; it hath made clear and terrible di≈øcoveries of tho≈øe Torments which attend ≈øinners in another World, and hath open'd to us the Trea≈øures of God's Wrath; ≈øo that now under the Go≈øpel, hell is naked before us, and de≈øtruction hath no covering; and this is one thing which makes the Go≈øpel ≈øo powerful an Engine to de≈øtroy ≈øin, Rom. 1.16, 18. The Go≈øpel is the power of God unto ≈øalvation; for therein is the wrath of God revealed
from heaven again≈øt all ungodline≈øs, and unrighteou≈øne≈øs of men.

3. Hopes of Pardon and Reward. And this, added to the former, renders the Go≈øpel the mo≈øt powerful In≈øtrument to take men off from ≈øin, and engage them to Holine≈øs, that can be imagin'd. The Means to draw Men from ≈øin, when they are once awaken'd with the fear of Vengeance, is hopes of Pardon and Mercy; and the way to encourage Obedience for the future, is hope of Reward. Now as an Argument to us to retreat and draw back from ≈øin, the Go≈øpel promi≈øes pardon and indempnity to us; and as an incitement to Holine≈øs, the Go≈øpel opens Heaven to us, and ≈øets before us everla≈øting Glory and Happine≈øs, and gives us the greate≈øt a≈ø≈øurance of it.
This is the Fir≈øt, The De≈øign of the Go≈øpel is rea≈øonable, in that it does eminently and directly ≈øerve the ends of Piety and Religion.

Secondly, This doth convince Men of the madne≈øs and folly of impenitency. Now the Wi≈ødom of God hath contrived ≈øuch a way of our Recovery, and by the Declaration of God's Wrath, and di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt ≈øin, hath given us ≈øuch Arguments to Repentance, and by di≈øcovering a way of Pardon and Mercy, hath given us ≈øuch encouragement to Repentance, how great mu≈øt the Folly of impenitency be? For con≈øider,

1. That impenitency Directly ≈øets it ≈øelf again≈øt the Wi≈ødom of God. If
after all this we continue in our Sins, we reject the coun≈øel of God again≈øt our ≈øelves, we de≈øpi≈øe the Wi≈ødom of God, and charge that with Folly; and we do it again≈øt our ≈øelves, to our own injury and ruine. If we live in our Sins, and cheri≈øh our lu≈øts, we directly oppo≈øe the end of our Redemtion, we contradict the great De≈øign of the Go≈øpel, we contemn the admirable Contrivance of God's Wi≈ødom, who ≈øent his Son into the World on purpo≈øe to de≈øtroy Sin; for we uphold that which he came to de≈øtroy, 1 John 3.5. Ye know that he was manife≈øted to take away our Sins. Now ≈øhall we continue in Sin, when we know, the Son of God was manife≈øted to take away Sin? God cannot but take it very ill at our hands, when he hath laid out the Riches of his Wi≈ødom in this de≈øign, for us to go about to defeat him in it; this is at once to be unthankful to God, and injurious to our ≈øelves; 'tis ≈øuch a madne≈øs, as if a condemned Man ≈øhould de≈øpi≈øe a Pardon, as if a Pri≈øoner ≈øhould be fond of his Fetters, and refu≈øe Deliverance; as if a Man, de≈øperately ≈øick ≈øhould fight with his Phy≈øician, and put away Health from him. If we do not comply with the wi≈ødom of God, which hath contrived our recovery; we
for≈øake our own mercy, and neglect a great Salvation; we love death, and hate our own Souls, Prov. 8.14, 15, 16.

2. Con≈øider, we cannot expect the wi≈ødom of God ≈øhould do more for our recovery, than hath been already done; the wi≈ødom of God will not try any further means. Mat. 21.37. la≈øt of all he ≈øent his Son. If we de≈øpi≈øe this way, if we tread under foot the Son of God, and count the blood of the Covenant, whereby we are ≈øanctified, an unholy thing, there will remain no more ≈øacrifice for ≈øin, Heb. 10.26, 29. What can expiate the guilt of ≈øin, if the Blood of Chri≈øt do not? What ≈øhall take us off from ≈øin, what ≈øhall ≈øanctifie us, if the blood of the Covenant be ineffectual? We re≈øi≈øt our la≈øt Remedy, and make void the be≈øt Means the Wi≈ødom of God could devi≈øe for our Recovery, if, after the revelation of the Go≈øpel, we continue in our Sins.

3. If we fru≈øtrate this De≈øign of God's Wi≈ødom for our Recovery, our Ruin will be the more dreadful and certain. Impenitency under the Go≈øpel will increa≈øe our Mi≈øery. If Chri≈øt had not come, we had had no ≈øin, in compari≈øon of what we now have; but now our ≈øin remains,
and there is no cloak for our ≈øin,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . We ≈øhall not be able at the day of Judgment to Preface any thing by way of Excu≈øe or Apology for our Impenitency. What ≈øhall we be able to ≈øay to the Ju≈øtice of God, when that ≈øhall condemn us, who rejected his Wi≈ødom, which would have ≈øaved us. We would all be ≈øaved, but we would be ≈øaved without Repentance; now the Wi≈ødom of God hath not found out any other way to ≈øave us from Hell, but by ≈øaving us from our ≈øins. And thou that will not ≈øubmit to this Method of Divine Wi≈ødom, take thy Cour≈øe, and let's ≈øee how thou wilt e≈øcape the damnation of hell. I will conclude all with tho≈øe dreadful words which the wi≈ødom of God pronounceth again≈øt tho≈øe that de≈øpi≈øe her, and refu≈øe to hearken to her Voice, Prov. 1.24, 25, 26. div.head: SERMON X.Vol. VI. The Ju≈øtice of God in the di≈øtribution of Rewards and Puni≈øhments.

q.p: Shall not the Judge of all the earth do right?

div.p: IN treating of the Attributes of God, I have con≈øidered tho≈øe which relate to the Divine ∆≤nder≈øtanding, viz. Knowledge and Wi≈ødom; I come now to con≈øider tho≈øe which relate to the Divine Will, viz. the≈øe four, the Ju≈øtice, the Truth, the Goodne≈øs, and the Holine≈øs of God. I begin with the Fir≈øt, namely, the Ju≈øtice of God.

At the 17 ver≈øe of this chapter, God, by a great and wonderful Conde≈øcention of his goodne≈øs, reveals to Abraham his Intention concerning the De≈øtruction of Sodom; upon this, Abraham v. 23. interceded with God for the ≈øaving of the Righteous Per≈øons, that were there; and to this end, he Pleads with God his Ju≈øtice and Righteou≈øne≈øs, with which he apprehended it to be in con≈øi≈øtent, to de≈øtroy the Righteous with the wicked, which, without a Miracle, could not be avoided in a general De≈øtruction. Wilt thou al≈øo de≈øtroy the Righteous, with the Wicked? Peradventure there be fifty Righteous within the City, wilt thou al≈øo de≈øtroy, and not ≈øpare the place for the fifty Righteous that are therein? that be far from thee to do after this manner, to ≈ølay the Righteous with the Wicked, and that the Righteous ≈øhould be as the Wicked, that be far from thee, ≈øhall not the Judge of all the Earth do right? This Negative Interrogation is equivalent to a vehement affirmation, ≈øhall not the Judge all the Earth do right? that is, undoubtedly he will. This we may take for a certain and undoubted Principle, that in the di≈øtribution of rewards and puni≈øhments the
Judge of the World will do Righteou≈øly.
So that the Argument that lies under our Con≈øideration is the Ju≈øtice of God in the di≈øtribution of Rewards and Puni≈øhments, for the clearing of which, we will con≈øider it,
Fir≈øt, In Hypothe≈øi, in regard to the particular Ca≈øe, which is here put by Abraham in the Text.
Secondly, In The≈øi, we will con≈øider it in General, in the Di≈øtribution of Rewards and Puni≈øhments.

Fir≈øt, We will con≈øider it in Hypothe≈øi, in regard to the particular Ca≈øe which is here put by Abraham in the Text, and the rather, becau≈øe if we look well into it, there is ≈øomething of real Difficulty in it, not ea≈øie to be cleared; for Abraham's rea≈øoning, if it be true, does plainly Conclude, that it would have been unrighteous with God in the de≈øtruction of Sodom, not to make a difference between the Righteous and the Wicked, but to involve them equally in the ≈øame common De≈øtruction. That be far from thee to do after this manner, to ≈ølay the Righteous with the Wicked, and that the Righteous ≈øhould be as the Wicked, that be far from
thee, ≈øhall not the Judge of all the Earth do right? as if he had ≈øaid, ≈øurely the Judge of all the Earth will never do ≈øo unrighteous a Thing.

And yet notwith≈øtanding this, we ≈øee it is very u≈øual for the Providence of God to involve good Men in general Calamities, and to make no vi≈øible difference between the Righteous and the Wicked. Now the difficulty is, how to reconcile the≈øe appearances of Providence with this rea≈øoning of Abraham in the Text.

And for the doing of this, I ≈øee but one po≈ø≈øible way, and that is this, that Abraham does not here ≈øpeak concerning the Judgments of God which befal Men in the ordinary Cour≈øe of his Providence, which many times happen promi≈øcuou≈øly, and involve good and bad Men in the ≈øame ruine; and the rea≈øon hereof is Plain, becau≈øe God in his ordinary Providence does permit the Cau≈øes, which produce the≈øe Judgments, to Act according to their own Nature, and they either cannot or will not make any di≈øtinction; for the Calamities which ordinarily happen in the World are produced by two ≈øorts of Cau≈øes either tho≈øe which we call Natural, or tho≈øe which are Voluntary.
Natural Cau≈øes, ≈øuch as Wind, and Thunder, and Storms, and the infection of the Air, and the like, the≈øe acting by a Nece≈ø≈øity of Nature, without any Knowledge or Choice, can make no di≈øtinction between the Good and the Bad. And the Voluntary Cau≈øes of Calamities, as Men are, they many times will make no difference between the Righteous and the Wicked; nay many times they are Maliciou≈øly bent again≈øt the Righteous, and the effects of their Malice fall heavie≈øt upon them. Now we ≈øay that things happen in the way of ordinary Providence, when Natural Cau≈øes are permitted to Act according to their Nature, and Voluntary Cau≈øes are left to their Liberty; and therefore in the cour≈øe of ordinary Providence, it is not to be expected that ≈øuch a di≈øtinction ≈øhould be made; it is neither po≈ø≈øible, nor does Ju≈øtice require it; it is not po≈ø≈øible, ≈øuppo≈øing Natural Cau≈øes left to Act according to their Nature, and Voluntary Cau≈øes to be left to their Liberty; nor does Ju≈øtice require it, for every Man is ≈øo much a Sinner, that no evil that befals him in this World, can be ≈øaid to be unju≈øt in re≈øpect of God.

So that Abraham is not here to be under≈øtood, as ≈øpeaking of ≈øuch Judgments as befal Men in the ordinary cour≈øe of God's Providence, in which, if the Good and Bad be involv'd alike, it cannot be expected to be otherwi≈øe, nor is there any inju≈øtice in it; but Abraham here ≈øpeaks of Miraculous and Extraordinary Judgments, which are immediately inflicted by God for the Puni≈øhment of ≈øome crying Sins, and the example of the World, to deter others from the like. And ≈øuch was this Judgment, which God intended to bring upon Sodom, and which Abraham hath Relation to in this Di≈øcour≈øe of his. In this Ca≈øe it may be expected from the Ju≈øtice of God, that a Difference ≈øhould be made between the-Righteous and the Wicked; and that for the≈øe Rea≈øons.

1. Becau≈øe this is a Judgment which God him≈øelf executes. It is not an Event of common Providence, which always follows the Nature of its Cau≈øe; but an Act of God, as a Judge. Now it is e≈ø≈øential to a Judge to make a Di≈øcrimination between the Good and the Bad, ≈øo as to puni≈øh the one, and ≈øpare the other; and this is as nece≈ø≈øary
to all proper Acts of Judgment in this World, as the other; there being no other difference between them, but that one is a Particular Judgment, and the other the General Judgment of the whole World.

2. When God goes out of the way of his ordinary Providence in Puni≈øhing, it may rea≈øonably be expected that he ≈øhould make a Difference between the Good and the Bad; for the Rea≈øon, why he does not in his common Providence is, becau≈øe he will not break and interrupt the e≈øtabli≈øht order of things, upon every little occa≈øion: But when he does go be≈øides the common cour≈øe of Things in puni≈øhing, the Rea≈øon cea≈øeth, which hindred him before from making a Difference; and 'tis rea≈øonable enough to expect, that in the inflicting of a Miraculous Judgment, a Miraculous Difference ≈øhould be made. Without making this difference, the end of the≈øe Miraculous Judgments would not be attained, which is, remarkably to puni≈øh the crying Sins of Men, and by that example to deter others from the like Sins: But if the≈øe Judgments ≈øhould fall promi≈øcuou≈øly upon the Righteous and the Wicked, it
would not be evident, that they were de≈øigned for the Puni≈øhment of ≈øuch Sins, when Men did ≈øee, that they fell likewi≈øe upon tho≈øe who were not guilty of tho≈øe Sins, and con≈øequently the example could not be ≈øo effectual to deter Men from Sin.

Upon all the≈øe accounts you ≈øee that Abraham's rea≈øoning was very Strong and well Grounded, as to tho≈øe Judgments which are Miraculous and Extraordinary, and immediately inflicted by God, for the Puni≈øhment of great and hainous Sins, which was the Ca≈øe he was ≈øpeaking of. And accordingly we find, that in the≈øe Judgments which have been Immediately and Miraculou≈øly inflicted by God, he hath always made this difference between the Righteous and the Wicked. In the Deluge which he brought upon the old World, the Spirit of God gives this Rea≈øon why the Judgment was ≈øo univer≈øal, becau≈øe all Fle≈øh had corrupted his way upon the Earth; and the Rea≈øon, why he ≈øaved Noah and his Family was, becau≈øe in this general corruption of Mankind, he alone was Righteous; thee have I ≈øeen Righteous before me in this Generation. So likewi≈øe in that Miraculous
Judgment of Korah and his Company, when God made a new thing, and the Earth opened her mouth to ≈øwallow them up, none peri≈øhed but he and his complices, the re≈øt had warning given them by God to remove from the tents of tho≈øe wicked Men. Thus you ≈øee that as to the particular Ca≈øe in the Text, Abraham's rea≈øoning concerning the Ju≈øtice of God is very firm, and concluding. I proceed to the

Second, Thing, which was that, which I principally intended to Di≈øcour≈øe upon, viz. to con≈øider the Ju≈øtice of God in general, in the di≈øtribution of Rewards and Puni≈øhments. And here I cannot but grant, that the be≈øt Evidence of this is yet wanting. We have clear demon≈øtrations of the Power and Wi≈ødom, and Goodne≈øs of God in this va≈øt and admirable frame of Things which we ≈øee: but we mu≈øt ≈øtay till the Day of Judgment for a clear and full Manife≈øtation of the Divine Ju≈øtice; for which Rea≈øon the Day of Judgment is in Scripture call'd, the Day of the Revelation of the Righteous Judgment of God. But in the mean time we may receive ≈øufficient a≈ø≈øurance of this, both from Natural Rea≈øon, and from Divine Revelation.

1. From Natural Rea≈øon, which tells us, that God loves Righteou≈øne≈øs and hates Iniquity, and con≈øequently that it mu≈øt be agreable to his Nature to countenance and encourage the one, and to di≈øcountenance the other; that is, to give ≈øome publick Te≈øtimony of his liking and Affection to the one, and of his Hatred and Di≈ølike of the other, which cannot otherwi≈øe be done, but by Rewards and Puni≈øhments.

But however the Heathen rea≈øoned about this matter, whatever premi≈øes they laid, they firmly believed the conclu≈øion, that God is Ju≈øt. Plato lays down this as a certain and undoubted Principle, that God is in no wi≈øe unju≈øt, but as Righteous, as is po≈ø≈øible, and that we cannot re≈øemble God more, than in this quality and di≈øpo≈øition. So likewi≈øe Seneca tells us, That the Gods are neither capable of receiving an injury, nor of doing any thing that is unju≈øt. Antoninus the great Emperour and Philo≈øopher, ≈øpeaking doubtfully, whether good Men are extingui≈øht by Death, or remain afterwards, If it be ju≈øt, ≈øays he, you may be ≈øure it is ≈øo: if it be not ju≈øt, you may certainly conclude the contrary,
for God is ju≈øt, and being ≈øo, he will do nothing that is unju≈øt or unrea≈øonable. And indeed the Heathen Philo≈øophers looked upon this as the great ≈øanction of all moral Precepts, that God was the Witne≈øs and the Avenger of the breach and violation of them, Qui ≈øecus faxit, deus ip≈øe vindex erit, If any Man do contrary to them, God him≈øelf will puni≈øh it; which ≈øhews, that there is a Natural Awe upon the Minds of Men of the Divine Ju≈øtice, which will overtake offenders either in this World or the other. But this will more clearly appear in the

2. Place, from Scripture, or Divine Revelation. And tho≈øe Texts which I ≈øhall produce to this purpo≈øe, may be reduced to the≈øe two Heads; either ≈øuch as prove the rectitude of the Divine Nature and his Ju≈øtice in general; or ≈øuch as ≈øpeak more particularly of the Ju≈øtice and Equity of his Providence in the di≈øtribution of Rewards and Puni≈øhments. I begin, fir≈øt, with tho≈øe which declare the rectitude of the Divine Nature, and the Ju≈øtice of God in general, and that either by attributing this Perfection to him, or by removing the contrary, inju≈øtice
and unrighteou≈øne≈øs at the greate≈øt di≈øtance from him.

1. Tho≈øe which attribute this Perfection to God. I ≈øhall mention but a few of many, P≈øal. 129.4. The Lord is Righteous. Dan. 9.7. O Lord! Righteou≈øne≈øs belongeth unto thee. This good Men have acknowledged, when they have lain under the hand of God, Ezra. 9.15. O Lord God of I≈ørael, thou art Righteous. And this the wor≈øt of Men have been forced to own, when they have been in extremity, Ex. 9.27. then Pharoah ≈øaid, the Lord is Righteous. This hath been likewi≈øe acknowledged by tho≈øe who have layn under the greate≈øt temptation to doubt of it, Jer. 12.1. Righteous art thou O Lord, when I plead with thee: yet let me talk with thee of thy judgments, wherefore doth the way of the wicked pro≈øper? The Prophet, notwith≈øtanding he ≈øaw the pro≈øperous Condition of wicked Men, and the afflicted ≈øtate of the godly, which ≈øeemed hard to be reconcile with the Ju≈øtice of God's Providence, yet before he would ≈øo much as rea≈øon about it, he lays down this as a certain conclu≈øion, Righteous art thou, O Lord. To this Head likewi≈øe
belong all tho≈øe Texts which ≈øpeak of Righteou≈øne≈øs, as God's dwelling Place and his Throne, of his Delight in Ju≈øtice, and of the Duration and Eternity of it, which I need not particularly recite.

2. There are likewi≈øe other Texts, which remove the contrary, viz. inju≈øtice and unrighteou≈øne≈øs at the greate≈øt di≈øtance from God, as being mo≈øt contrary to his Nature and Perfection. Deut. 32.4. A God of truth, and without iniquity. 2 Chron. 19.7. There is to iniquity with the Lord our God, nor accepting of Per≈øons, nor taking of Gifts. Job 8.3. Doth God pervert Judgment? or doth the Almighty pervert Ju≈øtice? which is a vehement negation of the Thing. Job 34.10, 11, 12. Far be it from God, that he ≈øhould do wickedne≈øs, and from the Almighty, that he ≈øhould commit iniquity. For the work of a Man ≈øhall he render unto him, and cau≈øe every Man to find according to his ways. Yea ≈øurely God will not do wickedly, neither will the Almighty pervert Judgment. Rom. 9.14. What ≈øhall we ≈øay then? is there unrighteou≈øne≈øs with God? God forbid.

Secondly, There are other Texts which ≈øpeak more particularly of the Ju≈øtice and Righteou≈øne≈øs of God in the di≈øtribution
of Rewards and Puni≈øhments. 'Tis true indeed, the Ju≈øtice of God doth not con≈øtantly appear in this World in the di≈øpen≈øations of his Providence becau≈øe this is a time of Patience and forbearance to Sinners, and of tryal and exerci≈øe to good Men; but there is a Day a coming, when all things ≈øhall be ≈øet ≈øtraight, and every Man ≈øhall receive the ju≈øt reward of his Deeds when the Ju≈øtice of God ≈øhall be evident to all the World, and every Eye ≈øhall ≈øee it, and ≈øhall acknowledge the Righteous Judgment of God; and this the Scripture mo≈øt clearly and expre≈øly declares unto us; and hence it is, that the Day of Judgment is call'd the Day of the Revelation of the Righteous Judgment of God. The Righteou≈øne≈øs of God doth not now ≈øo clearly appear, but that there are many Clouds over it; but there ≈øhall be a Day of Revelation, when the Righteou≈øne≈øs of God ≈øhall be made manife≈øt to all the World.

The remunerative Ju≈øtice of God ≈øhall then appear in the rewarding the Righteous; and the punitive Ju≈øtice of God in puni≈øhing the Wicked and Ungodly, ≈øo that a Man ≈øhall ≈øay, verily there is a reward for the Righteous, verily there is a God that judgeth the World.
Now the Righteou≈øne≈øs of this vengeance of God, which God will take upon Sinners, is further ≈øet forth to us in Scripture, from the Equity and Impartiality of it.
I. From the Equity of it,

1. In that the Sins of Men have ju≈øtly de≈øerved the Puni≈øhment, that ≈øhall come upon them, Rom. 1.32. Who knowing the judgment of God, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the righteous judgment of God, that they which commit ≈øuch things, are worthy of Death.

2. In that the Judgment of God ≈øhall be proportioned to the Degree and Heinou≈øne≈øs of Mens Sins; ≈øo as the le≈ø≈øer or greater Sins ≈øhall be puni≈øht with more or le≈øs Severity. So our Saviour threatens to tho≈øe who continue impenitent under the Go≈øpel and the advantages of it, their ca≈øe ≈øhall be more ≈øad than that of Tyre and Sidon, and it ≈øhall be more tolerable for Sodom and Gomorrah at the Day of Judgment, than for them. Mat. 11.20, 21. and Luke 12. 47, 48. There you have different Degrees of Puni≈øhment threatned, proportionable to the Aggravations of the Sins, which Men have committed; The ≈øervant which knew his Lord's will, and prepared
not him≈øelf, neither did according to his will, ≈øhall be beaten with many ≈øtripes: but he that knew it not, but did commit things worthy of ≈øtripes, ≈øhall be beaten with few ≈øtripes; and ≈øo proportionably of all other Aggravations of Sins, for to whom much is given, of him ≈øhall much be required, and unto whom Men have committed much, of him they will ask the more. So likewi≈øe God will vindicate the contempt of the Go≈øpel more ≈øeverely, than of the Law, becau≈øe the confirmation of it is clearer, and the Salvation offered by it greater. Heb. 2.2, 3, 4. If the word ≈øpoken by Angels was ≈øtedfa≈øt, and every tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion and di≈øobedience received a ju≈øt recompence of reward; how ≈øhall we e≈øcape? &c. And ≈øo, Heb. 10.28, 29. He that de≈øpi≈øed Mo≈øes his law died without mercy under two or three Witne≈ø≈øes, of how much ≈øorer puni≈øhment, ≈øuppo≈øe ye, ≈øhall he be thought worth, who haht troden under foot the Son of God? &c.

II. The Righteou≈øne≈øs of this Judgment is further ≈øet forth to us in Scripture by the impartiality of it. Hither belong all tho≈øe Texts, which remove from God that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that re≈øpect of Per≈øons, which is ≈øo incident to humane Tribunals. Now re≈øpect of Per≈øons
is in di≈øtribution of Ju≈øtice, and hath regard to ≈øome external qualities or circum≈øtances of the Per≈øons, which do not appertain to the merit of the cau≈øe, and upon Account of tho≈øe circum≈øtances, to deal unequally with tho≈øe, who≈øe Ca≈øe is equal; as when two Per≈øons, who are equally guilty of a Crime, are brought to their Tryal, and the one is Condemned, and the other acquitted, upon the Account of Friend≈øhip, or Relation, or ≈øome other Intere≈øt, becau≈øe one is Poor and the other Rich, the one hath powerful Friends to intercede for him, the other not, the one brings a Gift or Bribe, the other not, or upon any other account, be≈øides the pure Merits of the Cau≈øe; I ≈øay to deal thus in the di≈øtribution of of Ju≈øtice, is re≈øpect of Per≈øons. Otherwi≈øe in matters of meer grace and favour, re≈øpect of Per≈øons hath no Place, accordin ‚Ä¢ to that common rule of Divines, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
locum non habet in gratuitis, ≈øed in debitis. Now this the Scripture every where ≈øpeaks of, as a thing very far from God, Deut. 10.17. The Lord your God is God of gods, and Lord of lords, a great God, a mighty and a terrible, which regardeth not Per≈øons, nor taketh rewards.

Is it fit to ≈øay to a King, thou art Wicked? or to Princes, ye are ungodly? how much le≈øs to him that accepteth not the Per≈øons of Princes, nor regardeth the rich more than the poor? for they are all the work of his hands. Rom. 2.6. Who will render to every Man according to his deeds: for there is no re≈øpect of Per≈øons with God. Acts 10.34, 35. Of a truth I perceive that God is no re≈øpecter of Per≈øons, but in every Nation: he that feareth him, and worketh righteou≈øne≈øs, is accepted with him. Eph. 6.8, 9. The Apo≈øtle there pre≈ø≈øeth the duties of Servants to Ma≈øters, from this Con≈øideration, that what≈øoever good thing any Man doth, the ≈øame ≈øhall he receive of the Lord, whether he be bond or free, and at the 9th. v. Ye Ma≈øters, do the ≈øame thing unto them, forbearing threatning; knowing that your Ma≈øter al≈øo is in Heaven, neither is there re≈øpect of Per≈øons with him. He maketh this likewi≈øe an Argument, why Men ≈øhould not oppre≈øs and deal deceitfully one with another, Col. 3.25. But he that doth wrong, ≈øhall receive for the wrong which he hath done; and
there is no re≈øpect of Per≈øons. And in General, St. Peter urgeth this Con≈øideration upon all Men to deter them from Sin in any kind, 1 Pet. 1.17. And if ye call on the Father, who without re≈øpect of Per≈øons judgeth according to every Man's work, pa≈øs the time of your ≈øojourning here in fear.

And be≈øides that the Scripture doth remove this at the greate≈øt Di≈øtance from God, it gives us al≈øo ≈øeveral in≈øtances of the impartiality of the Divine Ju≈øtice, that it is not to be perverted and turned a≈øide by any of tho≈øe extrin≈øecal Con≈øiderations which commonly ≈øway with Men; it is not to be prevailed with and overcome by Flattery and Entreaties, Mat. 7.21, 22. Not every one that ≈øaith unto me, Lord, Lord, ≈øhall enter into the Kingdom of Heaven: but he that doth the will of my Father which is in Heaven, &c. The Divine Ju≈øtice is not to be impo≈øed upon by good Words, and external ≈øhews, and fal≈øe Profe≈ø≈øions; ≈øo neither by any external Relation to him; For many ≈øhall come from the Ea≈øt, and from the We≈øt, and ≈øhall ≈øit down with Abraham, I≈øaac, and Jacob, in the Kingdom of God, but the Children of the
