Kingdom ≈øhall be ca≈øt out into utter Darkne≈øs.

And however Men may bear up them≈øelves now upon their worldly Greatne≈øs and Power, certainly there is a time a coming, when the greate≈øt Per≈øons in the World, tho≈øe who overturn Kingdoms, and lay wa≈øt Countries, and oppre≈øs and ruin Millions of Mankind for the gratifying of their own Lu≈øts and Ambition, I ≈øay there is a Day coming, when even the≈øe, as much, nay more than others, ≈øhall fear and tremble before the impartial Ju≈øtice of God. Rev. 6.15. And the Kings of the earth, and the great Men, and the rich Men, and the chief Captains, and the mighty Men, and every Bond-man, and every Free-man hid them≈øelves in the Dens, and in the Rocks of the Mountains; for the great Day of his wrath is come, and who ≈øhall be able to ≈øtand? The impartial Ju≈øtice of God will treat the greate≈øt and the meane≈øt Per≈øons alike, Rev. 20.12. I ≈øaw the dead, ≈ømall and great, ≈øtand before God; and the books were opened, and another book was opened, which is the book of life; and the dead were judged out of tho≈øe things which were written in the books,
according to their works. All judged according to their Works.

I ≈øhould next proceed to vindicate the Ju≈øtice of God in the Di≈øtribution of Rewards and Puni≈øhments from tho≈øe Objections, which ≈øeem to impeach it. But before I enter upon this, it will be convenient to ≈øatisfie one que≈øtion, which hath occa≈øioned great di≈øputes in the World, and that is, how far Ju≈øtice, e≈øpecially as to the Puni≈øhment of Offenders is e≈ø≈øential to God? And for the clearing of this matter I ≈øhall briefly lay down the≈øe Propo≈øitions.

Fir≈øt, I take this for a certain and undoubted Truth, that every Perfection is e≈ø≈øential to God, and cannot be imagined to be ≈øeperated from the Divine Nature, becau≈øe this is the Natural Notion which Men have of God, that he is a Being that hath all Perfection.

Secondly, The actual con≈øtant exerci≈øe of tho≈øe Divine Perfections, the effects whereof are without him≈øelf, is not e≈ø≈øential to God. For in≈øtance, tho' God be e≈ø≈øentially powerful, and good; yet it is not nece≈ø≈øary, that he ≈øhould always exerci≈øe his Power and Goodne≈øs; but at ≈øuch times, and in ≈øuch a manner,
as ≈øeems be≈øt to his Wi≈ødom; and this is likewi≈øe true of his Wi≈ødom and Ju≈øtice, becau≈øe the≈øe are Perfections, the effects whereof are terminated upon ≈øomething without him≈øelf.

Thirdly, It is e≈ø≈øential to God to love Goodne≈øs, and hate Sin, wherever he ≈øees them. It is not nece≈ø≈øary there ≈øhould be a World, or rea≈øonable Creatures in it: but upon ≈øuppo≈øition that God makes ≈øuch Creatures, it is agreable to the Divine Nature, to give them good and righteous Laws, to encourage them in the doing of that which is good, and to di≈øcourage them from doing that which is evil, which cannot be done, but by Rewards and Puni≈øhments, and therefore it is agreable to the Perfection of the Divine Nature, to reward Goodne≈øs, and to puni≈øh Sin.
Fourthly, As for tho≈øe rewards which the Go≈øpel promi≈øeth, and the Puni≈øhments which it threatens, there is ≈øome difference to be made between the rewarding and puni≈øhing ju≈øtice of God.

1. As for that abundant reward God is plea≈øed to promi≈øe to good Men, the promi≈øe of it is founded in his goodne≈øs,
and the performance of that promi≈øe in his ju≈øtice; for it is ju≈øtice to perform what he promi≈øes, tho' the promi≈øe of ≈øo great and abundant a reward was meer goodne≈øs.

2. As for the puni≈øhing ju≈øtice of God, about which hath been the great Que≈øtion, whether that be e≈ø≈øential to God or not, it ≈øeems very plain, that it is not nece≈ø≈øary that God ≈øhould inflict tho≈øe judgments which he threatens, becau≈øe he hath threatned them; for there is not the like obligation upon Per≈øons to perform their threatnings, that there is to perform their promi≈øes; becau≈øe God by his promi≈øe becomes a Debtour to tho≈øe, to whom he makes the promi≈øe; but when he threatens, he is the Creditour, and we are Debtors to his Ju≈øtice; and as a Creditor, he may remit the Puni≈øhment which he hath threatned: But then if we con≈øider God as loving goodne≈øs and hating Sin; if we look upon him as Governor of the World, and concerned to pre≈øerve good Order, to encourage Holine≈øs and Righteou≈øne≈øs, and to di≈øcountenance Sin, under this con≈øideration it is e≈ø≈øential to him to puni≈øh Sin at ≈øuch times, and in ≈øuch manner
and circum≈øtances, as ≈øeems be≈øt to his Wi≈ødom.

And I am not at all moved by that, which is urged by ≈øome learned Men to the contrary, that if puni≈øhing ju≈øtice were e≈ø≈øential to God, then he mu≈øt puni≈øh the Sinner immediately, ≈øo ≈øoon as he hath offended, and to the utmo≈øt of his Power; becau≈øe whatever Acts naturally, Acts nece≈ø≈øarily, and to the utmo≈øt: for I do not ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øuch a ju≈øtice e≈ø≈øential to God as Acts nece≈ø≈øarily, but ≈øuch a ju≈øtice, which as to the time, and manner, and circum≈øtances of its Acting is regulated and determined by his Wi≈ødom; and there is the ≈øame Rea≈øon likewi≈øe of his goodne≈øs.
I come now to the Objections which are taken partly from the di≈øpen≈øations of God in this World; and partly from the puni≈øhments of the other.
Fir≈øt, As to the di≈øpen≈øations of God in this World, there are the≈øe two things Objected again≈øt the ju≈øtice of the Divine Providence.
I. The inequality of God's dealings with good and bad Men in this World.

II. The tran≈ølation of Puni≈øhments, puni≈øhing one Man's Sin upon another,
as the Sins of the Fathers upon the Children, of the Prince upon the People. I begin with the

I. Objection, the inequality of God's dealing with good and bad Men in this World. In this life things happen promi≈øcuou≈øly, there is one event to the righteous, and to the wicked; if the Wicked ≈øuffer and are afflicted, ≈øo are the Righteous; if the Righteous ≈øometimes flouri≈øh, ≈øo do the Wicked; and is not this unju≈øt, that tho≈øe who are ≈øo unequal as to their De≈øerts ≈øhould be equally dealt withal? or if there be any inequality, it is u≈øually the wrong way, the Wicked do many times pro≈øper more in the World, and the Righteous are frequently more afflicted. This was the great Objection of old again≈øt the Providence of God, which the Heathen Philo≈øophers took ≈øo much pains to an≈øwer, nay it did often ≈øhake the faith of Holy and Good Men in the old Te≈øtament. Job 12.6. The tabernacles of robbers pro≈øper, and they that provoke God are ≈øecure, into who≈øe hand God bringeth abundantly. and chap. 21.7, 8, 9. he Expo≈øtulates the ≈øame matter again; and David ≈øays this was a great ≈øtumbling-Block to him, P≈øal. 73.2, 3.
and the like we find in the Prophets, Jer. 12.1. and Hab. 1.13. This Objection I have el≈øe-where con≈øidered, I ≈øhall now very briefly offer two or three Things, which I hope will be ≈øufficient to break the force of it.

1. It mu≈øt be granted, that it is not nece≈ø≈øary to ju≈øtice to ≈øhew it ≈øelf immediately, and to di≈øpence Rewards and Puni≈øhments ≈øo ≈øoon as there are Objects for them. This is not thought nece≈ø≈øary among Men, much more ought we to leave it to the Wi≈ødom of God to determine the time and circum≈øtances of the exerci≈øing of his Ju≈øtice; and we are not to conclude that the Providence of God is unju≈øt, if he do not be≈øtow rewards, and inflict Puni≈øhments, ju≈øt when we think he ≈øhould.

2. If God intended this Life for a State of Tryal, wherein he would prove the obedience of Men, and their free inclination to good or evil, it is not rea≈øonable to expect that he ≈øhould follow Men with pre≈øent Rewards and Puni≈øhments; for that would lay too great a force upon Men, ≈øo that there would hardly be any oportunity of trying them; but on the contrary, there is all the Rea≈øon in the World to pre≈øume that
God ≈øhould exerci≈øe the Graces and Virtues of good Men with afflictions and ≈øufferings, and ≈øuffer bad Men to take their Cour≈øe for a while, and walk in their own ways, without continual Checks by frequent and remarkable Judgments upon them, ≈øo often as they offend.

The Puni≈øhment which overtook him at la≈øt, did quiet tho≈øe tumultuous
thoughts, and ab≈øolved the gods from all blame. When Men look but a little way, and con≈øider only the pre≈øent ≈øtate of Things, they are ready to quarrel at the Ju≈øtice of them; but if they would look at the end of Things, and have Patience to ≈øtay till the la≈øt, to ≈øee the Conclu≈øion and Winding up of things, they would then acquit God in their thoughts from all tho≈øe imputations of inju≈øtice, which from the inequality of pre≈øent di≈øpen≈øations, ra≈øh and incon≈øiderate Men are apt to charge him withal.

II. Objection, from the tran≈ølation of Puni≈øhments, the puni≈øhing of one Man's Sin upon another, as of the Fathers upon the Children, which God threatens in the ≈øecond Commandment, and did in ≈øome ≈øort fulfil in Ahab, in bringing the evil he had threatned him withal, in his Son's Days, 1 Kings 21.19. The puni≈øhing the Sin of one Per≈øon upon a People, as that of Achan upon the whole Congregation, Jo≈øh. 22.20. Did not Achan the ≈øon of Zerah commit a tre≈øpa≈øs in the accur≈øed thing? and wrath fell on all the congregation of I≈ørael, and that man peri≈øhed not alone in his iniquity. And the Sin of David upon the People,
2 Sam. 24. When ≈øeventy thou≈øand Dyed of the Plague, for David's Sin in numbring the People. Now how is this agreable to ju≈øtice? is it not a known Rule, Noxa caput ≈øequitur, Mi≈øchief pur≈øues the Sinner? What can be more rea≈øonable, Quam ut peccata ≈øuos teneant Authores, Than that Men's faults ≈øhould be charged upon the Authors, and Puni≈øhment fall upon the guilty?
For an≈øwer to this.

1. It is not unrea≈øonable that one Man ≈øhould bear the puni≈øhment of another's Fault, if he be willing and content to bear it, Volenti non fit injuria, There is no wrong done to tho≈øe, that are willing to undergo it, tho' they be innocent, which was the ca≈øe of our Ble≈ø≈øed Saviour ≈øuffering for us, the ju≈øt for the unju≈øt, as the Scripture expre≈ø≈øeth it.

2. Where the Per≈øon, upon whom the puni≈øhment is trasfer'd, is likewi≈øe a ≈øinner, and obnoxious to God, there can be no inju≈øtice; becau≈øe he hath de≈øerved it upon his own account, and God may take what occa≈øion he plea≈øeth to puni≈øh them that de≈øerve to be puni≈øht.

3. In puni≈øhing the iniquity of the Father upon the Children, the guilty Per≈øon, that is, the Father, is puni≈øht in the
Calamity of his Children, for a Man's Children are him≈øelf Multiplyed; and therefore it is very remarkable that in the ≈øecond Commandment, God promi≈øeth to ≈øhew mercy to thou≈øands of Generations of them that love him; but he vi≈øits the iniquities of the Fathers upon the Children, but to the third and fourth Generation, that is ≈øo far as a Man may live to ≈øee them puni≈øht, and ≈øuffer in their Puni≈øhment.

4. As to the Puni≈øhment of the People for the ≈øins of their Princes and Governors, and one part of a community for another, ≈øuppo≈øing all of them to be Sinners, which is the true ca≈øe, God may lay the puni≈øhment where he plea≈øeth; and there is no more inju≈øtice then when a Man is whipt on the Back for the theft which his hand committed, a community being one Body; be≈øides the Prince is puni≈øht in the lo≈øs of his People, the glory of a King con≈øi≈øting in the Multitude of his Subjects.
The Objection with re≈øpect to the other World, the puni≈øhment of temporal Evils with Eternal, is el≈øe-where an≈øwer'd.
The u≈øe we ≈øhould make of this whole Di≈øcour≈øe is,

Fir≈øt, If God be Ju≈øt and Righteous, let us acknowledge it in all his di≈øpen≈øations, even in tho≈øe, the Rea≈øon whereof is mo≈øt hidden and ob≈øcure. Neh. 9.33. Speaking of the great afflictions that had befal'n God's own People, yet this he lays down as a firm Principle, howbeit thou art ju≈øt in all that is brought upon us.

Secondly, This is matter of terrour to wicked Men. God doth now exerci≈øe his milder Attributes towards Sinners, his Mercy, and Patience, and Goodne≈øs; but if we de≈øpi≈øe the≈øe, that terrible Attribute of his Ju≈øtice will de≈øplay it ≈øelf; and this the Scripture de≈øcribes in a ≈øevere manner, the Lord revengeth, and is jealous; the Lord will take vengeance on his Adver≈øaries, and re≈øerveth wrath for his Enemies.

Thirdly, This is matter of comfort to good Men, that the Righteous God Governs the World, and will judge it. The Lord reigneth, let the earth rejoyce, P≈øal. 97.1. And he gives the Rea≈øon of it in the next v. Righteou≈øne≈øs and judgment are the habitation of his Throne. Tho' he be omnipotent, we need not fear; for his Power is always under the conduct of Eternal Righteou≈øne≈øs.

Fourthly, Let us imitate this righteou≈øne≈øs, let us endeavour to be righteous as he is righteous; let us give to God the Love, Reverence, and Obedience which are due to him; and in all our dealings, what is ju≈øt and due to Men. This Duty hath an immutable Rea≈øon, founded in the Nature of God.

div.head: SERMON XII.Vol. VI. The Truth of God.

q.p: ‚ÄîA God of Truth.

div.p:
IN ≈øpeaking to this Attribute, I ≈øhall
I. Shew you what we are to under≈øtand by the Truth of God.
II. Endeavour to prove that this Perfection belongs to God, that he is a God of Truth.
III. An≈øwer ≈øome Objections that may be made again≈øt it; and then make ≈øome ∆≤≈øe of it.

I. What we are to under≈øtand by the Truth of God. I ≈øhall take it as the Scripture u≈øeth it in a large Sen≈øe, ≈øo as
to include not only the veracity of God; but his Faithfulne≈øs. Hence it is that in Scripture Truth and Faithfulne≈øs are ≈øo often put together, and frequently put one for another, I≈øa. 25.1. Thy coun≈øels of old are faithfulne≈øs and truth. Rev. 21.5. The≈øe words are true and faithful. And the Faithfulne≈øs of God, in performing his Promi≈øes, is frequently call'd his Truth. And becau≈øe the Scripture u≈øeth them promi≈øcuou≈øly, we need not be very ≈øolicitous to find out di≈øtinct Notions of them; but if you will, they may be di≈øtingui≈øht thus; the truth or veracity of God hath place in every Declaration of his Mind; the Faithfulne≈øs of God only in his Promi≈øes.

For the Fir≈øt, The veracity or truth of God; this hath place in every Declaration of his Mind, and ≈øignifies an exact Corre≈øpondence and Conformity between his Word and his Mind, and con≈øequently between his Word and the truth and reality of Things. The Corre≈øpondence of his Word with his Mind, depends upon the rectitude of his Will; the conformity of his Word with the reality of Things, not only upon the rectitude of his Will, but the Perfection of his Knowledge, and the infallibility of his
∆≤nder≈øtanding; ≈øo that when we ≈øay God is true, or ≈øpeaks Truth, we mean thus, that his Words are a plain Declaration of his Mind, and a true repre≈øentation of Things, in oppo≈øition to Fal≈øe-hood, which is ≈øpeaking otherwi≈øe than the thing is; and Hypocri≈øie, that is, ≈øpeaking otherwi≈øe than we think. For in≈øtance, when God declares any thing to be ≈øo, or not to be ≈øo, to have been thus, or not to have been thus, the thing really is ≈øo, and he thinks ≈øo; when he expre≈ø≈øeth his de≈øire of any thing, he does really de≈øire it; when he commands any thing, or forbids us any thing, it is really his Mind and Will that we ≈øhould do what he Commands, and avoid what he forbids; when he declares and foretels any thing future, it really ≈øhall come to pa≈øs, and he really intended it ≈øhould; if the Declaration be to be under≈øtood ab≈øolutely, it ≈øhall ab≈øolutely come to pa≈øs; if the Declaration be to be under≈øtood Conditionally, it ≈øhall come to pa≈øs, and he intends it ≈øhall, if the Condition be performed.

Secondly, The Faithfulne≈øs of God. This only hath place in his Promi≈øes, in which
there is an Obligation of Ju≈øtice ≈øuperadded to his Word; for God by his Promi≈øe doth not only declare what he intends, and what ≈øhall be; but confers a right upon them to whom the promi≈øe is made, ≈øo as that the breach of his Promi≈øe would not only ca≈øt an imputation upon his Truth, but upon his Ju≈øtice.
II. That this Perfection belongs to God. And this I ≈øhall endeavour to prove,
Fir≈øt, From the Dictates of Natural Light.
Secondly, From Scripture.

Fir≈øt, From the Dictates of Natural Light. Natural Light tells us, that Truth and Faithfulne≈øs are Perfections, and con≈øequently belong to the Divine Nature; and that Fal≈øe-hood and a Lie are Imperfections, and to be removed from God. There is nothing that is among≈øt Men e≈øteemed a greater contumely and reproach, than to give a Man the Lie, to call him a Lyar, becau≈øe it is an Argument of ≈øo much ba≈øene≈øs, and of a low and mean and ≈øervile ≈øpirit; the u≈øual Temptation to it being fear of lo≈øing ≈øome Advantage, or incurring
≈øome danger. Hence was that ≈øaying, that it is the property of a Slave to lie, but of a free Man to ≈øpeak truth: Now whatever argues ba≈øene≈øs or imperfection, our Rea≈øon tells us is infinitely to be ≈øeparated from the mo≈øt Perfect Being. God cannot be tempted with evil, the Divine Nature being all-≈øufficient, can have no temptation to be otherwi≈øe than Good and Ju≈øt, and True and Faithful. Men are tempted to Lie by advantage, and out of fear: but the Divine Nature hath the ≈øecurity of its fullne≈øs and all-≈øufficiency, that it cannot hope for any increa≈øe, nor fear any impairment of its E≈øtate. I. What we are to under≈øtand by the Holine≈øs of God. There is ≈øome difficulty in fixing the proper Notion of ‚Ä¢ t; for tho' there be no Property more frequently attributed to God in Scrip

II. I ≈øhall endeavour to prove that this Perfection belongs to God;

1. If Holine≈øs be a Perfection of the Divine Nature, and a Property of God, if in the Notion of God, there be included an everla≈øting ≈øeparation and di≈øtance from Moral Imperfection, an eternal repugnance to Sin and Iniquity; from hence we may infer, that there is an intrin≈øecal good and evil in Things, and the Rea≈øons and Re≈øpects of moral

Therefore they do not ≈øeem to me to ≈øpeak ≈øo ≈øafely, who make the Divine Will, preci≈øely and ab≈øtractedly con≈øider'd, the Rule of Moral good and evil, as if there were nothing good or evil in its own Nature antecedently to the Will of God, but that all things are therefore good or evil, becau≈øe God Wills them to be ≈øo; for if this were ≈øo, Goodne≈øs, and Righteou≈øne≈øs, and Truth, and Faithfulne≈øs would not be e≈ø≈øential, and nece≈ø≈øary, and immutable Properties of the Divine Nature, but accidental, and arbitrary, and uncertain, and mutable; which is to ≈øuppo≈øe that God, if he plea≈øed, might be otherwi≈øe than good, and ju≈øt, and true. 2. If Holine≈øs be the chief Excellency and Perfection of the Divine Nature, this ≈øhews us what account we are to make of Sin, and Wickedne≈øs, and Vice. If Holine≈øs be the Chief Excellency and Perfection of the Divine Nature, then what an ab≈øurd and unrea≈øonable thing is it, to ≈øcorn and de≈øpi≈øe Holine≈øs, to mock and deride men under this very Title! 4. If God be a Holy God, and

5. Imitate the Holine≈øs of God; this is the Inference here in the Text, be ye holy; for I am holy. Holine≈øs, in one word, contains all the imitable Perfections of God; and when it is ≈øaid, be ye holy, 'tis as much as if

1. Holine≈øs is an imitation of the highe≈øt Excellency and Perfection. Holine≈øs, I told you, ≈øignifies a ≈øeparation from Sin and Vice, and all moral Imperfection, and con≈øequently, doth comprehend and take in all the moral Perfections of the Divine Nature, the Goodne≈øs, and Mercy, and Patience, and Ju≈øtice, and Veracity, and Faithfulne≈øs of God; now the≈øe are the very Beauty and Glory of the Divine Nature. The fir≈øt thing that we attribute to God, next to his Being, is his Goodne≈øs, and tho≈øe other Attributes which have a nece≈ø≈øary connexion with it; for his Greatne≈øs and Maje≈øty is nothing el≈øe but the Glory which re≈øults from his united Perfections, e≈øpecially from his Goodne≈øs, and tho≈øe Perfections which are akin to it. Separate from God the≈øe Perfections which Holine≈øs includes in it, and what would be left but an Omnipotent Evil, an Eternal Being infinitely Knowing, and infinitely able to do mi≈øchief? which is as plain and notorious a Contradiction, and as impo≈ø≈øible a thing as can be-imagin'd;
≈øo that if we have any ≈øparks of ambition in us, we cannot but a≈øpire after Holine≈øs, which is ≈øo great an Excellency and Perfection of God him≈øelf. There is a vulgar prejudice again≈øt Holine≈øs, as if it were a poor mean thing, and below a great and generous Spirit; whereas Holine≈øs is the only true greatne≈øs of Mind, the mo≈øt genuine Nobility, and the highe≈øt gallantry of Spirit; and however it be de≈øpi≈øed by Men, it is of a Heavenly Extraction, and Divine Original. Holine≈øs is the fir≈øt part of the Character of the wi≈ødom that is from above. Jam. 3.17. The wi≈ødom that is from above, is fir≈øt pure, then peaceable, gentle, and ea≈øie to be entreated, full of mercy, and good fruits, without partiality, and without hypocri≈øie.

2. Holine≈øs is an e≈ø≈øential and principal ingredient of Happine≈øs. Holine≈øs is a ≈øtate of Peace and Tranquillity, and the very frame and temper of Happine≈øs; and without it, the Divine Nature, as it would be imperfect, ≈øo it would be mi≈øerable. If the Divine Nature were capapable

of envy, or malice, or hatred, or revenge, or impatience, or cruelty, or inju≈øtice, or unfaithfulne≈øs, it would be liable to vexation and di≈øcontent, than which nothing can be a greater di≈øturbance of Happine≈øs: ≈øo that Holine≈øs is nece≈ø≈øary to our Felicity and Contentment; not only to the happine≈øs of the next life, but to our pre≈øent Peace and Contentment. If rea≈øonable Creatures could be happy, as brute Bea≈øts are in their degree, by enjoying their depraved Appetites, and following the Dictates of Sen≈øe and Fancy, God would not have bound us up to a Law and Rule, but have left us, as he hath done unrea≈øonable Creatures, to ≈øatisfie our Lu≈øts and Appetites, without check and control: but Angels and Men, which are rea≈øonable Creatures, have the Notions of Good and Evil, of Right and Wrong, of Comline≈øs and Filthine≈øs, ≈øo woven and twi≈øted into their very Natures, that they can never be wholly defaced, without the ruine of their Beings; and therefore it is impo≈ø≈øible that ≈øuch Creatures ≈øhould
be happy otherwi≈øe, than by complying with the≈øe Notions, and obeying the natural Dictates and Sugge≈øtions of their Minds; which if they neglect, and go again≈øt, they will naturally feel remor≈øe and Torment in their own Spirits; their Minds will be unea≈øie and unquiet, and they will be inwardly grieved and di≈øplea≈øed with them≈øelves for what they have done. So the Apo≈øtle tells us, Rom. 1. That even the mo≈øt degenerate Heathens had Con≈øciences which did accu≈øe or excu≈øe them, according as they obeyed, or did contrary to the dictates of Natural Light. God therefore, who knows our frame, hath ≈øo adapted his Law to us, which is the rule of holine≈øs, that if we live up to it, we ≈øhall avoid the un≈øpeakable torment of a guilty Con≈øcience; whereas, if we do contrary to it, we ≈øhall always be at di≈øcord with our ≈øelves, and in a perpetual di≈øquiet of Mind; for nothing can do contrary to the Law of its Being, that is, to its own Nature, without
di≈øplea≈øure and reluctancy, the con≈øequence of which, in Moral Actions, is Guilt, which is nothing el≈øe, but the Trouble and Di≈øquiet which ari≈øeth in one's Mind, from con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of having done ≈øome thing that contradicts the perfective Principle of his Being, that is ≈øomething which did not become him, and which, being what he is, that is a rea≈øonable Creature, he ought not to do.

So that in all rea≈øonable Creatures there is a certain kind of Temper and Di≈øpo≈øition that is nece≈ø≈øary and e≈ø≈øential to Happine≈øs, and that is Holine≈øs; which as it is the Perfection, ≈øo it is the great Felicity of the Divine Nature: And on the contrary, this is one chief part of the Mi≈øery of tho≈øe wicked and accur≈øed Spirits the Devils, and of unholy Men, that they are of a temper contrary to God, they are Envious, and Malicious, and Wicked, that is, of ≈øuch a temper as is naturally a Torment and Di≈øquiet to it ≈øelf; and here the
foundation of Hell is laid in the evil di≈øpo≈øition of our Spirits, and till that be cured, which can only be done by Holine≈øs, 'tis as impo≈ø≈øible for a wicked Man to be happy, and contented in him≈øelf, as it is for a Sick Man to be at ea≈øe; and the external pre≈øence of God, and a local Heaven would ≈øignifie no more to make a wicked Man happy and contented, than heaps of Gold, and Con≈øorts of Mu≈øick, and a well ≈øpread Table, and a rich Bed, would contribute to a Man's ea≈øe in the paroxy≈øms of a Feaver, or in a violent fit of the Stone. If a ≈øen≈øual, or covetous, or ambitious Man were in Heaven, he would be like the rich Man in Hell, he would be tormented with a continual Thir≈øt, and burnt up in the Flames of his own ardent De≈øires, and would not meet with the lea≈øt drop of ≈øuitable Plea≈øure and Delight, to quench and allay the Heat; the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe ≈øuch a Man hath that within him which torments him, and he cannot be at ea≈øe,
till that be removed. Sin is the violent and unnatural and unea≈øie State of our Soul, every wicked Man's Spirit is out of order, and till the Man be put into a right Frame by Holine≈øs, he will be perpetually di≈øquieted, and can have no re≈øt within him≈øelf. The Prophet fitly de≈øcribes the condition of ≈øuch a Per≈øon, I≈øa. 57.20, 21. But the wicked are like the troubled ≈øea when it cannot re≈øt, who≈øe waters ca≈øt forth mire and dirt; there is no peace ≈øaith my God, to the wicked. So long as a Man is unholy, ≈øo long as filthine≈øs and corruption abound in his Heart, they will be re≈øtle≈øty working, like Wine which is in a perpetual motion and agitation, till it have purged it ≈øelf of its Dregs and Foulne≈øs. Nothing is more turbulent and unquiet than the Spirit of a wicked Man; it is like the Sea, when it roars and rages through the ≈øtrengh of contrary Winds; it is the ≈øcene of furious Lu≈øts and wild Pa≈ø≈øions, which as they are contrary to Holine≈øs, ≈øo they maintain perpetual
conte≈øts and fewds among them≈øelves.

All Sin ≈øeparates us from God, who is the Foundation of our Happine≈øs. Our limited Nature, and the narrowne≈øs of our Beings, will not permit us to be happy in our ≈øelves; it is peculiar to God to be his own Happine≈øs; but Man, becau≈øe he is finite, and therefore cannot be ≈øelf-≈øufficient, is carried forth by an innate de≈øire, of Happine≈øs, to ≈øeek his Felicity in God. So that there is in the nature of man a Spring of re≈øtle≈øs Motion, which with great impatience forceth him out of him≈øelf, and to≈ø≈øes him to and fro, till he comes to re≈øt in ≈øomething that is ≈øelf-≈øufficient. Our Souls, when they are ≈øeparated from God, like the unclean Spirit in the Go≈øpel, when it was ca≈øt out, they wander up and down in dry and de≈øart places, ≈øeeking re≈øt, but finding none. Were the whole World calm about a Man, and did it not make the lea≈øt attempt upon him, were he free from the fears of Divine Vengeance; yet he could
not be ≈øatisfied with him≈øelf, there is ≈øomething within him that would not let him be at re≈øt, but would tear him from his own Foundation and Con≈øi≈øtency; ≈øo that when we are once broken off from God, the ≈øen≈øe of inward want doth ≈øtimulate and force us to ≈øeek our contentment el≈øe-where. So that nothing but Holine≈øs, which re-unites us to God, and re≈øtores our Souls to their primitive and original ≈øtate, can make us happy, and give peace and re≈øt to our Souls. And this is the con≈øtant voice and language of Scripture, and the tenour of the Bible. Acquaint thy ≈øelf with God, that thou maye≈øt be at Peace. Job 22.21. Light is ≈øown for the righteous, and gladne≈øs for the upright in heart, P≈øal. 97.11. The work of righteou≈øne≈øs is peace, and the effect of righteou≈øne≈øs, quietne≈øs and a≈ø≈øurance for ever, I≈øa. 32.17.

Seeing then Holine≈øs is ≈øo high a Perfection, and ≈øo great a Happine≈øs, let the≈øe Arguments prevail with us, to a≈øpire after this temper, that as he who hath called us is holy, ≈øo we may be holy in all manner of Conver≈øation, becau≈øe it is written, be ye holy, for I am holy.

div.head:
SERMON XIV.Vol. VI. Of doing Good. Being a Spital Sermon, Preach'd at Chri≈øt-Church on Ea≈øter-Tue≈øday,

q.p: Let us not be weary in well doing, forin due ≈øea≈øon we ≈øhall reap, if we faint not: As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all Men, e≈øpecially unto them who are of the hou≈øhold of faith.

div.p: THE Apo≈øtle in the≈øe Words recommends unto us a great and comprehen≈øive Duty, the doing of good; concerning which the Text offers the≈øe five particulars to our Con≈øideration.

list.item: I. The Nature of the Duty it ≈øelf, which is called well doing, v. 9. and doing good v. 10.
II. The extent of this Duty, in re≈øpect of it's Object, which is all Mankind, Let us do good unto all men, e≈øpecially unto them, who are of the hou≈øhold of faith.
III. The mea≈øure of it, as we have opportunity.

V. The Argument and Encouragement to it, becau≈øe in due ≈øea≈øon we ≈øhall reap, if we faint not: Therefore as we have opportunity, let us do good, &c.

div.p:
I. I will con≈øider the Nature of the Duty it ≈øelf; of well doing, and doing good. And this I ≈øhall explain to you as briefly as I can, by con≈øidering the extent of the Act of
doing Good, and the Excellency of it. And

1. The extent of the Act. It comprehends in it all tho≈øe ways wherein we may be beneficial and u≈øeful to one another. It reaches not only to the Bodies of Men, but to their Souls, that Better and more Excellent part of our ≈øelves; and is conver≈øant in all tho≈øe Ways and Kinds, whereby we may ≈øerve the temporal, or ≈øpiritual Good of our Neighbour, and promote either his pre≈øent, or his future and eternal Happine≈øs.

To in≈øtruct the Ignorant, or reduce tho≈øe that are in Error; to turn the di≈øobedient to the wi≈ødom of the ju≈øt, and reclaim tho≈øe that are engaged in any evil Cour≈øe, by good Coun≈øel, and ≈øea≈øonable Admonition, and by prudent and kind Reproof; to re≈øolve and ≈øatisfie the doubting Mind; to confirm the weak; to heal the broken-hearted, and to comfort the melancholy and troubled Spirits. The≈øe are the
noble≈øt Ways of Charity, becau≈øe they are conver≈øant about the Souls of Men, and tend to procure and promote their eternal Felicity.

And then to feed the hungry, to cloath the naked, relea≈øe the impri≈øoned; to redeem the Captives, and to vindicate tho≈øe who are injur'd and oppre≈øs'd in their Per≈øons, or E≈øtates, or Reputation; to repair tho≈øe who are ruin'd in their Fortunes; and, in a word, to relieve and comfort tho≈øe who are in any kind of Calamity or Di≈øtre≈øs.

All the≈øe are but the ≈øeveral Branches and In≈øtances of this great Duty here in the Text, of doing good; tho' it hath, in this place, a more particular re≈øpect to the Charitable ≈øupply of tho≈øe, who are in Want and Nece≈ø≈øity; and therefore with a more particular regard to that, I ≈øhall Di≈øcour≈øe of it at this time. You ≈øee the extent of the Duty. We will in the

2. Place, briefly ≈øay ≈øomething of the Ecellency of it, which will appear, if we con≈øider, That it is the imitation of the highe≈øt Excellency and Perfection. To do Good, is to be like God, who is Good, and doth good; and it is to be like to him, in that which he e≈øteems his greate≈øt Glory. It is to be like the Son of God, who, when he was plea≈øed to take our Nature upon him, and live here below, and to dwell among≈øt us, went about doing good. And it is to be like the ble≈ø≈øed Angels, the highe≈øt Rank and Order of God's Creatures; who≈øe great Employment it is to be mini≈øtring Spirits, for the good of Men. So that for a Man to be kind, and helpful, and beneficial to others, is to be a good Angel, and a Saviour, and a kind of God too.

It is an Argument of a great, and noble, and generous Mind, to extend our Thoughts and Cares to the concernments of others, and to employ our intere≈øt, and power, and
endeavours for their benefit and advantage: Whereas a low, and mean, and narrow Spirit, is contracted and ≈øhrivel'd up within it ≈øelf, and cares only for its own things, without any regard to the good and happine≈øs of others.

It is the mo≈øt noble work in the World, becau≈øe that inclination of Mind, which prompts us to do good, is the very temper and di≈øpo≈øition of Happine≈øs. Solomon, after all his Experience of worldly greatne≈øs and plea≈øure, at la≈øt pitched upon this, as the great felicity of humane Life, and the only good U≈øe that is to be made of a pro≈øperous and plentiful Fortune. Eccle≈ø. 3.12. I know (≈øays he, ≈øpeaking of Riches) that there is no good in them, but for a Man to rejoice and do good in his life. And certainly the be≈øt way to take joy in an E≈øtate, is to do good with it; and a greater and wi≈øer than Solomon has ≈øaid it, even he who is the Power and Wi≈ødom of God has ≈øaid it,
that it is a more ble≈ø≈øed thing to give than to receive.

Con≈øider farther, That this is one of the great and ≈øub≈øtantial parts of Religion, and next to the love and honour, which we pay to Almighty God, the mo≈øt acceptable Service that we can do to him; it is one Table of the Law, and next the Fir≈øt and great Commandment, of loving the Lord our God, and very like to it. And the ≈øecond is like unto it, (≈øays our Saviour) Thou ≈øhalt love thy Neighbour as thy ≈øelf; like to it, in the excellency of it; and equal to it, in the nece≈ø≈øary obligation of it. For this Commandment (≈øays St. John, 1 Epi≈øt. Chap. 4. v. 21). we have from him, that he who loveth God, love his Brother al≈øo. The Fir≈øt Commandment indeed excels in the dignity of the Object, becau≈øe it enjoins the Love of God; but the ≈øecond ≈øeems to have the advantage in the reality of its Effects: for the Love of God con≈øi≈øts in our acknowledgment, and honour of him; but our righteou≈øne≈øs and goodne≈øs extends
not to him; we can do him no real Benefit and Advantage: But our love to Men is really U≈øeful and Beneficial to them; for which rea≈øon, God is contented in many ca≈øes, that the external Honour and Wor≈øhip which he requires of us by his po≈øitive Commands, ≈øhould give way to that Natural Duty of Love and Mercy which we owe to one another. I will have mercy (≈øays God in the Prophet Amos) and not ≈øacrifice.

And to ≈øhew how great a value God puts upon this Duty, he hath made it the very Te≈øtimony of our love to him≈øelf; and for want of it, hath declared that he will reject all our other Profe≈ø≈øions and Te≈øtimonies of love to him, as fal≈øe and in≈øincere. Who ≈øo hath this worlds good, (≈øaith St. John, 1 Epi≈øt. 3.17.) and ≈øeeth his Brother have need, and ≈øhutteth up his bowels of compa≈ø≈øion from him, how dwelleth the love of God in him? And again, Chap. 4. ver. 20. If any man ≈øay, I love God, and hateth his Brother, he is a lyar; for he
that loveth not his Brother, whom he hath ≈øeen, how can he love God, whom he hath not ≈øeen?
You ≈øee the Duty here recommended, both in the Extent and in the Excellency of it; let us do good. I proceed to con≈øider, in the

II. Place, the Extent of this Duty, in re≈øpect of its Object, which is all Mankind, but more e≈øpecially Chri≈øtians, tho≈øe that are of the ≈øame Faith and Religion. Let us do good unto all men, e≈øpecially unto tho≈øe that are of the hou≈øhold of Faith. So that the Object, about which this Duty is conver≈øant, is very large, and takes in all Mankind; let us do good unto all men. The Jews confined their Love and Kindne≈øs to their own Kindred and Nation; and becau≈øe they were prohibited familiarity with Idolatrous Nations, and were enjoined to maintain a perpetual Enmity with Amalek, and the ≈øeven Nations of Canaan, whom God had ca≈øt out before them, and devoted to Ruin; they looked upon
them≈øelves as perfectly di≈øcharg'd from all Obligation of Kindne≈øs to the re≈øt of Mankind: And yet it is certain, that they were expre≈øly enjoin'd by their Law, to be kind to Strangers, becau≈øe they them≈øelves had been Strangers in the Land of Egypt. But our Saviour hath re≈øtored this Law of Love and Charity to its Natural and Original extent; and hath declared every one that is of the ≈øame nature with our ≈øelves to be our Neighbour, and our Brother; and that he is to be treated by us accordingly, when ever he ≈øtands in need of our kindne≈øs and help; and to ≈øhew that none are out of the compa≈øs of our Charity, he hath expre≈øly commanded us to extend it to tho≈øe, who of all others can lea≈øt pretend to it, even our Enemies and Per≈øecutors.
So that if the Que≈øtion be about the extent of our Charity in general, the≈øe two things are plainly enjoined by the Chri≈øtian Religion.

1. Negatively, That we ≈øhould not hate or bear ill-will to any man, or do him any harm or mi≈øchief. Love worketh no Evil to his Neighbour, (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) Rom. 13.10. And this negative Charity every Man may exerci≈øe towards all Men, without Exception, and that equally; becau≈øe it does not ≈øignifie any po≈øitive Act, but only that we ab≈øtain from Enmity and Hatred, from Injury and Revenge, which it is in every Man's power, by the Grace of God, and the due care and government of him≈øelf, to do.

2. Po≈øitively, The Law of Charity requires, that we ≈øhould bear an univer≈øal good-will to all Men, and wi≈øh every Man's happine≈øs, and pray for it, as ≈øincerely as we wi≈øh and pray for our own; and if we be ≈øincere in our Wi≈øhes, and Prayers for the good of others, we ≈øhall be ≈øo in our Endeavours to procure and promote it.

But the great difficulty is, as to the exerci≈øe of our Charity, and the real Expre≈ø≈øions and Effects of it, in doing good to others; which is the Duty here meant in the Text, and (as I told you before) does more particularly relate to the Relief of tho≈øe who are in Want and Nece≈ø≈øity. And the rea≈øon of the difficulty is, becau≈øe no Man can do good to all in this kind, if he would; it not being po≈ø≈øible for any Man to come to the knowledge of every man's Nece≈ø≈øity and Di≈øtre≈øs; and if he could, no man's Ability can po≈ø≈øibly reach to the ≈øupply and the relief of all men's Wants. And indeed this limitation the Text gives to this Duty; as we have opportunity (≈øays the Apo≈øtle) let us do good unto all men; which either ≈øignifies, as occa≈øion is offered, or as we have Ability of doing, or both; as I ≈øhall ≈øhew afterwards.

So that it being impo≈ø≈øible to exerci≈øe this Charity to all Men that ≈øtand in need of it, 'tis nece≈ø≈øary
to make a difference, and to u≈øe Prudence and Di≈øcretion in the Choice of the mo≈øt fit and proper Objects. We do not know the Wants of all men, and therefore the bounds of our Knowledge do of nece≈ø≈øity limit our Charity within a certain compa≈øs; and of tho≈øe whom we do know, we can relieve but a ≈ømall part, for want of Ability; from whence it follows, that tho' a man were never ≈øo Charitably di≈øpo≈øed, yet he mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity ≈øet ≈øome Rules to him≈øelf, for the management of his Charity to the be≈øt advantage. What tho≈øe Rules are, cannot minutely and nicely be determined; when all is done, much mu≈øt be left to every man's prudence and di≈øcretion, upon a full view and con≈øideration of the Ca≈øe before him, and all the Circum≈øtances of it; but yet ≈øuch general Rules may be given, as may ≈øerve for the direction of our Practice in mo≈øt Ca≈øes; and for the re≈øt, every man's prudence, as well as it can, mu≈øt determine the matter. And the Rules which I ≈øhall give, ≈øhall be the≈øe.

Fir≈øt, Ca≈øes of Extremity ought to take the fir≈øt place, and do for that time challenge precedence of all other Con≈øiderations. If a Per≈øon be in great and pre≈øent Di≈øtre≈øs, and his Nece≈ø≈øity ≈øo urgent, that if he be not immediately relieved, he mu≈øt peri≈øh; this is ≈øo violent a Ca≈øe, and calls ≈øo loud for pre≈øent help, that there is no re≈øi≈øting of it, whatever the Per≈øon be; though a perfect Stranger to us, though mo≈øt unworthy, though the greate≈øt Enemy we have in the World, yet the greatne≈øs of his Di≈øtre≈øs does ≈øo ≈øtrongly plead for him, as to ≈øilence all Con≈øiderations to the contrary; for after all, he is a man, and is of the ≈øame Nature with our ≈øelves, and the con≈øideration of Humanity ought, for that time, to prevail over all Objections again≈øt the Man, and to prefer him to our Charity, before the neare≈øt Relation and Friend, who is not in the like Extremity. In other ca≈øes, we not only may, but ought to
relieve our Friends, and tho≈øe that have de≈øerved well of us in the fir≈øt place: but if our Enemy be in Extremity, then that Divine Precept takes place, if thine Enemy hunger, feed him; if he thir≈øt, give him to drink.

Secondly, In the next place, I think, that the Obligation of Nature, and the nearne≈øs of Relation, does challenge a Preference; for there is all the Rea≈øon in the World, if other things be equal, that we ≈øhould con≈øider and ≈øupply the nece≈ø≈øity of tho≈øe, who are of our Blood and Kindred, and Members of our Family, before the Nece≈ø≈øities of Strangers, and tho≈øe who have no relation to us. There is a ≈øpecial Duty incumbent upon us, and another Obligation be≈øide that of Charity, to have a particular Care and Regard for them. In this ca≈øe not only Chri≈øtianity, but Nature tyes this Duty upon us, 1 Tim. 5.8. If any man provide not for his own, e≈øpecially for his Dome≈øticks, for them
that are of his Family, he hath denyed the Faith, and is wor≈øe than an Infidel; that is, he doth not only offend again≈øt the Law of Chri≈øtianity, but again≈øt the very Dictates of Nature, which prevail even among≈øt the Infidels.
